{{other uses|Goal (disambiguation)}} {{POV|talk=Neutrality issue|date=June 2018}} [[File:Millennium Development Goals, UN Headquarters, New York City, New York - 20080501.jpg|thumb|A poster at [[United Nations Headquarters]] showing [[Millennium Development Goals]]]] A '''goal''' is an idea of the future or desired result that a person or a group of people envisions, [[Planning|plans]] and commits to achieve.{{cite book |last1=Locke |first1=Edwin A. |authorlink1=Edwin A. Locke |last2=Latham |first2=Gary P. |date=1990 |title=A theory of goal setting & task performance |location=Englewood Cliffs, NJ |publisher=[[Prentice Hall]] |isbn=978-0139131387 |oclc=20219875}} People endeavor to reach goals within a finite time by setting [[Time limit|deadline]]s. A goal is roughly similar to a [[purpose]] or aim, the anticipated result which guides reaction, or an [[Intrinsic value (ethics)#End|end]], which is an [[object (philosophy)|object]], either a [[physical object]] or an [[abstract object]], that has [[Intrinsic value (ethics)|intrinsic value]]. ==Goal setting== {{Main|Goal setting}} Goal-setting theory was formulated based on [[empirical research]] and has been called one of the most important theories in organizational psychology.{{Cite journal|last=Miner, J. B.|first=|date=2003|title=The rated importance, scientific validity, and practical usefulness of organizational behavior theories: A quantitative review|url=|journal=AOM Learning and Education|volume=2|issue=3|pages=250–268|via=|doi=10.5465/amle.2003.10932132}} [[Edwin A. Locke]] and Gary P. Latham, the fathers of goal-setting theory, provided a comprehensive review of the core findings of the theory in 2002.{{cite journal |last1=Locke |first1=Edwin A. |authorlink1=Edwin A. Locke |last2=Latham |first2=Gary P. |date=September 2002 |origyear=2002 |title=Building a practically useful theory of goal setting and task motivation: a 35-year odyssey |journal=[[American Psychologist]] |volume=57 |issue=9 |pages=705–717 |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.57.9.705|citeseerx=10.1.1.126.9922 }} In summary, Locke and Latham found that specific, difficult goals lead to higher performance than either easy goals or instructions to "do your best", as long as [[feedback]] about progress is provided, the person is committed to the goal, and the person has the ability and knowledge to perform the task.{{cite journal |last1=Stajkovic |first1=Alexander D. |last2=Locke |first2=Edwin A. |authorlink2=Edwin A. Locke |last3=Blair |first3=Eden S. |date=September 2006 |title=A first examination of the relationships between primed subconscious goals, assigned conscious goals, and task performance |journal=[[Journal of Applied Psychology]] |volume=91 |issue=5 |pages=1172–1180 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.91.5.1172 |pmid=16953778}} According to Locke and Latham, goals affect performance in the following ways: # goals direct attention and effort toward goal-relevant activities, # difficult goals lead to greater effort, # goals increase persistence, with difficult goals prolonging effort, and # goals indirectly lead to [[arousal]], and to discovery and use of task-relevant knowledge and strategies. A positive relationship between goals and performance depends on several factors. First, the goal must be considered important and the individual must be committed. Participative goal setting can help increase performance, but participation itself does not directly improve performance. [[Self-efficacy]] also enhances goal commitment.{{cite journal |last1=Stajkovic |first1=Alexander D. |last2=Luthans |first2=Fred |date=September 1998 |title=Self-efficacy and work-related performance: a meta-analysis |journal=Psychological Bulletin |volume=124 |issue=2 |pages=240–261 |doi=10.1037/0033-2909.124.2.240}} For goals to be effective, people need feedback that details their progress in relation to their goal. Some [[Coaching|coaches]] recommend establishing specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bounded ([[SMART criteria|SMART]]) objectives, but not all researchers agree that these [[SMART criteria]] are necessary.{{cite journal |last=Grant |first=Anthony M |title=An integrated model of goal-focused coaching: an evidence-based framework for teaching and practice |date=September 2012 |journal=International Coaching Psychology Review |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=146–165 (147) |url=http://coachingconsultinginternational.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/An-integrated-model-of-goal-focused-coaching-Grant-ICPR-2012.pdf |quote=Whilst the ideas represented by the acronym SMART are indeed broadly supported by goal theory (e.g. Locke, 1996), and the acronym SMART may well be useful in some instances in coaching practice, I think that the widespread belief that goals are synonymous with SMART action plans has done much to stifle the development of a more sophisticated understanding and use of goal theory within in the coaching community, and this point has important implications for coaching research, teaching and practice. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129080651/http://coachingconsultinginternational.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/An-integrated-model-of-goal-focused-coaching-Grant-ICPR-2012.pdf |archivedate=2014-11-29}} The SMART framework does not include goal difficulty as a criterion; in the goal-setting theory of Locke and Latham, it is recommended to choose goals within the 90th percentile of difficulty, based on the average prior performance of those that have performed the task.{{Cite journal|last=Locke, E. A., Chah, D., Harrison, S. & Lustgarten, N.|first=|date=1989|title=Separating the effects of goal specificity from goal level|url=|journal=Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes|volume=43|issue=2|pages=270–287|via=|doi=10.1016/0749-5978(89)90053-8}} Goals can be long-term, intermediate, or short-term. The primary difference is the time required to achieve them.{{cite book|last1=Creek |first1=Jennifer |last2=Lougher |first2=Lesley |chapter=Goal setting |title=Occupational therapy and mental health |year=2008 |edition=4th |publisher=Churchill Livingstone Elsevier |location=Edinburgh; New York |isbn=9780443100277 |oclc=191890638 |pages=111–113 (112) |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=4YnQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA112 |quote=Client goals are usually set on two or three levels. Long-term goals are the overall goals of the intervention, the reasons why the client is being offered help and the expected outcome of intervention... Intermediate goals may be clusters of skills to be developed, attitudes to be changed or barriers to be overcome on the way to achieving the main goals... Short-term goals are the small steps on the way to achieving major goals.}} Short-term goals expect accomplishment in a short period of time, such as trying to get a bill paid in the next few days. The definition of a short-term goal need not relate to any specific length of time. In other words, one may achieve (or fail to achieve) a short-term goal in a day, week, month, year, etc. The time-frame for a short-term goal relates to its context in the overall time line that it is being applied to. For instance, one could measure a short-term goal for a month-long project in days; whereas one might measure a short-term goal for someone's lifetime in months or in years. Planners usually define short-term goals in relation to long-term goals. === Mindset theory of action phases === Before an individual can set out to achieve a goal, they must first decide on what their desired end-state will be. [[Peter Gollwitzer]]'s mindset theory of action phases proposes that there are two phases in which an individual must go through if they wish to achieve a goal.Gollwitzer, P. M. (2012). Mindset theory of action phases. In P. A. M. Van Lange. A. W. Kruglanski, & E. T. ''Handbook of motivation science'' (pp. 235–250). New York: [[Guilford Press]]. For the first phase, the individual will mentally select their goal by specifying the criteria and deciding on which goal they will set based on their commitment to seeing it through. The second phase is the planning phase, in which that individual will decide on which set of behaviors are at their disposal and will allow them to best reach their desired end-state or goal.Deckers, Lambert (2018). ''Motivation: biological, psychological, and environmental'' (5th ed.). New York: [[Routledge]]. pp. 342–348. {{ISBN|9781138036321}}. ==Personal goals== Individuals can [[personal goal setting|set personal goals]]. A student may set a goal of a high mark in an exam. An athlete might run five miles a day. A traveler might try to reach a destination-city within three hours. Financial goals are a common example, to save for retirement or to save for a purchase. Managing goals can give returns in all areas of [[personal life]]. Knowing precisely what one wants to achieve makes clear what to concentrate and improve on, and often subconsciously prioritizes that goal. However, successful goal adjustment (goal disengagement and goal re-engagement capacities) is also a part of leading a healthy life.{{Cite journal|last=Wrosch|first=Carsten|last2=Scheier|first2=Michael F.|last3=Miller|first3=Gregory E.|date=2013-12-01|title=Goal Adjustment Capacities, Subjective Well-Being, and Physical Health|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4145404/|journal=Social and Personality Psychology Compass|volume=7|issue=12|pages=847–860|doi=10.1111/spc3.12074|issn=1751-9004|pmc=4145404|pmid=25177358}} [[Goal setting]] and planning ("goal work") promotes long-term [[Vision statement|vision]], intermediate [[Mission statement|mission]] and short-term [[motivation]]. It focuses intention, [[Desire (emotion)|desire]], acquisition of knowledge, and helps to organize resources. Efficient goal work includes recognizing and resolving all [[Guilt (emotion)|guilt]], inner conflict or limiting [[belief]] that might cause one to sabotage one's efforts. By setting clearly defined goals, one can subsequently measure and take pride in the accomplishment of those goals. One can see progress in what might have seemed a long, perhaps difficult, grind. ===Achieving personal goals=== Achieving complex and difficult goals requires focus, long-term diligence and effort (see [[Goal pursuit]]). Success in any field requires forgoing excuses and justifications for poor performance or lack of adequate planning; in short, success requires emotional maturity. The measure of belief that people have in their ability to achieve a personal goal also affects that achievement. Long-term achievements rely on short-term achievements. [[Emotion]]al control over the small moments of the single day makes a big difference in the long term. ===Personal goal achievement and happiness=== There has been a lot of research conducted looking at the link between achieving desired goals, changes to self-efficacy and integrity and ultimately changes to [[subjective well-being]].{{cite book |last=Emmons |first=Robert A |chapter=Striving and feeling: personal goals and subjective well-being |editor1-last=Gollwitzer |editor1-first=Peter M. |editor1-link=Peter Gollwitzer |editor2-last=Bargh |editor2-first=John A |editor2-link=John Bargh |title=The psychology of action: linking cognition and motivation to behavior |year=1996 |publisher=[[Guilford Press]] |location=New York |pages=313–337 |isbn=978-1572300323 |oclc=33103979 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=v1LQVSI9hfMC&pg=PA313}} Goal efficacy refers to how likely an individual is to succeed in achieving their goal. Goal integrity refers to how consistent one's goals are with core aspects of the self. Research has shown that a focus on goal efficacy is associated with well-being factor happiness (subjective well-being) and goal integrity is associated with the well-being factor [[meaning (psychology)]].{{cite journal |last1=McGregor |first1=Ian |last2=Little |first2=Brian R |title=Personal projects, happiness, and meaning: on doing well and being yourself |journal=[[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] |date=February 1998 |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=494–512 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.74.2.494 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/13739275}} Multiple studies have shown the link between achieving long-term goals and changes in subjective well-being; most research shows that achieving goals that hold personal meaning to an individual increases feelings of subjective well-being.{{cite journal |last=Brunstein |first=Joachim C |title=Personal goals and subjective well-being: a longitudinal study |journal=[[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] |date=November 1993 |volume=65 |issue=5 |pages=1061–1070 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.65.5.1061}}{{cite journal |last1=Elliott |first1=Andrew J |last2=Sheldon |first2=Kennon M |title=Avoidance personal goals and the personality–illness relationship |journal=[[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] |date=November 1998 |volume=75 |issue=5 |pages=1282–1299 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.75.5.1282|citeseerx=10.1.1.433.3924 }}{{cite journal |last1=Sheldon |first1=Kennon M |last2=Kasser |first2=Tim |title=Pursuing personal goals: skills enable progress but not all progress is beneficial |journal=[[Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin]] |date=December 1998 |volume=24 |issue=12 |pages=1319–1331 |doi=10.1177/01461672982412006 |url=http://web.missouri.edu/~sheldonk/pdfarticles/PSPB98skills.pdf}} ==Self-concordance model== The self-concordance model is a model that looks at the sequence of steps that occur from the commencement of a goal to attaining that goal.{{cite journal |last1= Sheldon |first1= Ken M |last2= Eliott |first2= Andrew J |title= Goal striving, need satisfaction and longitudinal well-being: the self-concordance model |journal= [[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] |date= March 1999 |volume= 76 |issue= 3 |pages= 482–497 |doi= 10.1037/0022-3514.76.3.482 |url= http://web.missouri.edu/~sheldonk/pdfarticles/JPSP99.pdf}} It looks at the likelihood and impact of goal achievement based on the type of goal and meaning of the goal to the individual.{{cn|date=February 2016}} Different types of goals impact both goal achievement and the sense of [[subjective well-being]] brought about by achieving the goal. The model breaks down factors that promote, first, striving to achieve a goal, then achieving a goal, and then the factors that connect goal achievement to changes in subjective well-being. ===Self-concordant goals=== Goals that are pursued to fulfill intrinsic values or to support an individual's self-concept are called self-concordant goals. Self-concordant goals fulfill basic needs and align with what [[psychoanalyst]] [[Donald Winnicott]] called an individual's "[[True Self]]". Because these goals have personal meaning to an individual and reflect an individual's self-identity, self-concordant goals are more likely to receive sustained effort over time. In contrast, goals that do not reflect an individual's internal drive and are pursued due to external factors (e.g. social pressures) emerge from a non-integrated region of a person and are therefore more likely to be abandoned when obstacles occur.{{cite book |last1= Gollwitzer |first1= Peter M. |authorlink= Peter Gollwitzer |chapter= Action phases and mind-sets |editor1-last= Higgins |editor1-first= E Tory |editor2-last= Sorrentino |editor2-first= Richard M |title= Handbook of motivation and cognition: foundations of social behavior |year= 1990 |publisher= [[Guilford Press]] |location= New York |pages= 53–92 |volume= 2 |isbn= 978-0898624328 |oclc= 12837968 |chapterurl= http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/90Goll_ActionPhasesMindSets.pdf}}
Those who attain self-concordant goals reap greater well-being benefits from their attainment. Attainment-to-well-being effects are mediated by need satisfaction, i.e., daily activity-based experiences of [[autonomy]], competence, and relatedness that accumulate during the period of striving. The model is shown to provide a satisfactory fit to 3 longitudinal data sets and to be independent of the effects of [[self-efficacy]], implementation intentions, avoidance framing, and [[life skills]].{{cite journal |last1= Sheldon |first1= Kennon M |last2= Elliot |first2= Andrew J |title= Goal striving, need satisfaction, and longitudinal well-being: the self-concordance model |journal= [[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]] |volume= 76 |issue= 3 |date= March 1999 |pages= 482–497 |doi= 10.1037/0022-3514.76.3.482 |url= http://web.missouri.edu/~sheldonk/pdfarticles/JPSP99.pdf}}
Furthermore, [[self-determination theory]] and research surrounding this theory shows that if an individual effectively achieves a goal, but that goal is not self-endorsed or self-concordant, well-being levels do not change despite goal attainment.{{cite journal |last= Ryan |first= Richard M |title= Self-determination theory and the facilitation of intrinsic motivation, social development, and well-being |journal= [[American Psychologist]] |date= January 2000 |volume= 55 |issue= 1 |pages= 68–78 |doi= 10.1037/0003-066x.55.1.68 |url= http://selfdeterminationtheory.org/SDT/documents/2000_RyanDeci_SDT.pdf|citeseerx= 10.1.1.529.4370 }} ==Goal management in organizations== In [[organization]]s, goal management consists of the process of recognizing or inferring goals of individual [[team]]-members, abandoning goals that are no longer relevant, identifying and resolving conflicts among goals, and prioritizing goals consistently for optimal team-collaboration and effective operations. For any successful [[commerce|commercial]] [[system]], it means deriving [[Profit (economics)|profits]] by making the best quality of [[good (accounting)|goods]] or the best quality of [[Service (economics)|services]] available to end-users ([[customer]]s) at the best possible [[cost]].{{cn|date=May 2017}} Goal management includes: * assessment and dissolution of non-rational blocks to success * [[time management]] * frequent reconsideration (consistency checks) * [[Feasibility study| feasibility]] checks * adjusting [[Milestone (project management)|milestones]] and main-goal targets [[Jens Rasmussen (human factors expert)]] and Morten Lind distinguish three fundamental categories of goals related to technological system management:{{cite book |last1= Rasmussen |first1= Jens |authorlink1= Jens Rasmussen (human factors expert) |last2= Lind |first2= Morten |chapter= A model of human decision making in complex systems and its use for design of system control strategies |title= Proceedings of the 1982 American Control Conference: Sheraton National Hotel, Arlington, Virginia, June 14–16, 1982 |publisher= [[American Automatic Control Council]] |date= 1982 |location= New York |oclc= 761373599 |chapterurl= http://www.risoe.dk/rispubl/reports_INIS/RISOM2349.pdf}} Cited in: {{cite book |last= Wrench |first= Jason S |year= 2013 |chapter= Communicating within the modern workplace: challenges and prospects |editor-last= Wrench |editor-first= Jason S |title= Workplace communication for the 21st century: tools and strategies that impact the bottom line |location= Santa Barbara, CA |publisher= [[Praeger Publishers|Praeger]] |pages= 1–38 |isbn= 978-0313396311 |oclc= 773022358 |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=xtg672jRCfAC&pg=PA4}} # production goals # safety goals # economy goals Organizational goal-management aims for individual employee goals and objectives to align with the vision and strategic goals of the entire organization. Goal-management provides organizations with a mechanism{{which?|date=May 2017}} to effectively communicate corporate goals and strategic objectives to each person across the entire organization.{{cn|date=May 2017}} The key consists of having it all emanate from a pivotal source and providing each person with a clear, consistent organizational-goal message so that every employee understands how their efforts contribute to an enterprise's success.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} An example of goal types in [[business management]]: * Consumer goals: this refers to supplying a product or service that the market/consumer wants{{cite book |last1= Osterwalder |first1= Alexander |author-link1= Alexander Osterwalder |last2= Pigneur |first2= Yves |author-link2= Yves Pigneur |last3= Clark |first3= Tim |title= Business model generation: a handbook for visionaries, game changers, and challengers |year= 2010 |location= Hoboken, NJ |publisher= [[John Wiley & Sons]] |isbn= 9780470876411 |oclc= 648031756 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=L3TnC7ZAWAsC}} * Product goals: this refers to supplying an outstanding [[value proposition]] compared to other products - perhaps due to factors such as quality, design, reliability and novelty{{cite book |last1= Barnes |first1= Cindy |last2= Blake |first2= Helen |last3= Pinder |first3= David |title= Creating & delivering your value proposition: managing customer experience for profit |year= 2009 |location= London; Philadelphia |publisher= [[Kogan Page]] |isbn= 9780749455125 |oclc= 320800660 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=8d73CPt_khwC}} * Operational goals: this refers to running the organization in such a way as to make the best use of [[management skills]], technology and resources * Secondary goals: this refers to goals which an organization does not regard as priorities{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} ==Goal displacement== Goal displacement occurs when the original goals of an entity or organization are replaced over time by different goals. In some instances, this creates problems, because the new goals may exceed the capacity of the mechanisms put in place to meet the original goals. New goals adopted by an organization may also increasingly become focused on internal concerns, such as establishing and enforcing structures for reducing common employee disputes.Karen Kirst-Ashman, ''Human Behavior, Communities, Organizations, and Groups in the Macro Social Environment'' (2007), p. 112. In some cases, the original goals of the organization become displaced in part by repeating behaviors that become traditional within the organization. For example, a company that manufactures widgets may decide to do seek good publicity by putting on a fundraising drive for a popular charity, or having a tent at a local county fair. If the fundraising drive or county fair tent is successful, the company may choose to make this an annual tradition, and may eventually involve more and more employees and resources in the new goal of raising the most charitable funds, or having the best county fair tent. In some cases, goals are displaced because the initial problem is resolved or the initial goal becomes impossible to pursue. A famous example is the [[March of Dimes]], which began as an organization to fund the fight against [[polio]], but once that disease was effectively brought under control by the [[polio vaccine]], transitioned to being an organization for combating [[birth defect]]s. ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Big Hairy Audacious Goal]] * [[Decision-making software]] * [[Direction of fit]] * [[GOAL agent programming language]] * [[Goal modeling]] * [[Goal orientation]] * [[Goal programming]] * [[GQM|Goal–Question–Metric]] (GQM) * [[Goal theory]] * [[Management by objectives]] * [[Moving the goalposts]] * [[OKR|Objectives and Key Results]] (OKR) * [[Polytely]] * [[Regulatory focus theory]] * [[Strategic management]] * [[Strategic planning]] * [[SWOT analysis]] * [[The Goal (novel)|''The Goal'' (novel)]] * ''[[The Jackrabbit Factor]]'' {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Mager |first=Robert Frank |title=Goal analysis: how to clarify your goals so you can actually achieve them |year=1997 |origyear=1972 |location=Atlanta, GA |publisher=Center for Effective Performance |edition=3rd |isbn=978-1879618046 |oclc=37435274}} * {{cite book |editor1-last=Moskowitz |editor1-first=Gordon B |editor1-link=Gordon Moskowitz |editor2=Heidi Grant Halvorson |year=2009 |title=The psychology of goals |location=New York |publisher=[[Guilford Press]] |isbn=9781606230299 |oclc=234434698}} [[Category:Management]] [[Category:Motivation]] [[Category:Goal| ]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Great Fire of 1901 |Image_Name = 1901JacksonvilleFireMap.jpg |Imagesize = 300px |Image_Alt = |Image_Caption = Map of the Great Fire of 1901 that destroyed [[Downtown Jacksonville]] |Thumb_Time = |AKA = |Participants = |Location = [[Jacksonville, Florida]] |Date = May 3, 1901 |Result = 2,368 structures destroyed
7 killed |Fatalities = |URL = }} The '''Great Fire of 1901''' was a conflagration that occurred in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], on May 3, 1901. It was one of the worst disasters in [[History of Florida|Florida history]] and the third largest urban fire in the U.S., next to the [[Great Chicago Fire]], and the [[1906 San Francisco fire]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2009-oct-the-great-jacksonville-fire-of-1901 |title=The Great Jacksonville Fire of 1901 |last=Davis |first=Ennis |date=2009-10-20 |website=Metro Jacksonville |language=en |access-date=2018-05-01 |df=mdy-all}} ==Fire== ===Origin=== In 1901, Jacksonville was a city which consisted mainly of wooden buildings with wood shingled roofs. The city itself had been suffering under a prolonged drought,{{Cite news |url=https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-55458480/like-the-phoenix-jacksonville-rose-from-the-ashes |title=Like the Phoenix, Jacksonville Rose from the Ashes after the Great Fire |last=Kerr |first=Jessie-Lynne |date=1999-05-02 |work=The Florida Times Union |access-date=2018-05-01 |language=en |via=Questia|df=mdy-all}} leaving the building exteriors across the city dry and fire-prone. At around noon on Friday, May 3, 1901, workers at the Cleaveland Fibre Factory, located on the corner of Beaver and Davis Streets, left for lunch. Several minutes later, sparks from the chimney of a nearby building started a fire in a pile of [[Spanish moss]] that had been laid out to dry. First, factory workers tried to put it out with a few buckets of water, as they had frequently done on similar occasions.{{Cite web |url=http://www.library.ufl.edu/spec/pkyonge/jacksonville/jaxfire2.html |title=The Fire! |website=The Great Fire of Jacksonville: An Artistic Description of a Gloomy Affair |publisher=University of Florida Library |access-date=2018-05-01|df=mdy-all}} However, the blaze was soon out of control due to the wind picking up out of the east.Foley, Bill; Wood, Wayne W. (2001). ''The Great Fire of 1901''. Published by The Jacksonville Historical Society, Jacksonville, FL A brisk northwest wind fanned the flames, which "spread from house to house, seemingly with the rapidity that a man could walk". [[Image:Forsyth-st-ruins.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Forsyth Street ruins.]] In eight hours, the fire burned 146 city blocks, destroyed more than 2,368 buildings, and left almost 10,000 residents homeless. It is said the glow from the flames could be seen in [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah]], Georgia, and the smoke plumes in [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]], North Carolina.{{cite book|last=Davis|first=T. Frederick|title=History of Jacksonville Florida and Vicinity 1513 to 1924|year=1925|publisher=The Florida Historical Society|location=Florida Heritage Collection|pages=513}} James Weldon Johnson, principal of a local school claimed, however, that firemen tried to save the fire from spreading to a white neighborhood, allowing black parts of town to burn down in the process:
"We met many people fleeing. From them we gathered excitedly related snatches: the fiber factory catches afire - the fire department comes - fanned by a light breeze, the fire is traveling directly east and spreading out to the north, over the district where the bulk of Negroes in the western end of the city live - the firemen spend all their efforts saving a low row of frame houses just across the street on the south side of the factory, belonging to a white man named Steve Melton."{{Cite web |url=https://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2014-feb-10-facts-about-jacksonvilles-black-history/page/3 |title=10 Facts About Jacksonville's Black History |last=Davis |first=Ennis |date=2014-02-10 |website=Metro Jacksonville |language=en |access-date=2018-01-10 |df=mdy-all}}
===Aftermath=== Florida Governor [[William S. Jennings]] declared [[martial law]] in Jacksonville and dispatched several state [[militia]] units to help. Reconstruction began immediately, and the city was returned to civil authority on May 17. Seven human deaths were reported.{{cite web|title=Great Jacksonville Fire of 1901|url=https://www.floridamemory.com/photographiccollection/photo_exhibits/jacksonvillefire/|publisher=Florida Memory|accessdate=April 18, 2015}} [[St. Andrew's Episcopal Church (Jacksonville, Florida)|St. Andrew's Episcopal Church]], built of bricks in 1887, was the only major church in the city to withstand the fire. The [[Duval County Courthouse]] and all its real estate records were destroyed in the fire. To this day real estate deeds in Duval County refer either to "the current public records of Duval County, Florida" or, if the records predate the fire, "the former public records of Duval County, Florida." It is the only county in Florida for which that is the case.{{cn|date=May 2018}} The only existing pre-Fire real estate records are title abstracts saved by Title and Trust, a title company that still charges for their use.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ===Reconstruction=== New York City architect [[Henry John Klutho]] helped rebuild the city. He and other architects, enamored by the "[[Prairie Style]]" of architecture then being popularized by architect [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] in Chicago and other Midwestern cities, designed exuberant local buildings with a Florida flair. Buildings designed by Klutho were [[Dyal-Upchurch Building]] (1902), [[Jacksonville_Public_Library#Carnegie_Library|Carnegie Library]] (1905), [[Laura_Street_Trio#Bisbee_Building|Bisbee Building]] (1909), [[Morocco Temple]] (1910), and the [[Florida Baptist Building]] (1924) While many of Klutho's buildings were demolished or abandoned by the 1980s, several of his creations remain including his most prominent work the [[St. James Building]]. The Jacksonville City Hall currently uses the St. James Building.{{cite news | title=Dyal-Upchurch – then and now | last=Penland | first=Dolly | url=http://jacksonville.bizjournals.com/jacksonville/stories/2007/04/02/tidbits4.html | publisher=''[[Jacksonville Business Journal]]'' | date=March 30, 2007 | accessdate=2009-12-14|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web | last=Wood | first=Wayne | url=http://www.jaxhistory.com/Jax%20Arch%20Herit/D-27.htm | title=Jacksonville's Architectural Heritage, Dyal-Upchurch Building | accessdate=2009-12-14}} Local charity [[Fresh Ministries]] recently{{when|date=January 2013}} restored the Klutho Apartments, in [[Springfield (Jacksonville)|Springfield]], and converted them into office space for the Community Development Corporation's Operation New Hope.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Jacksonville has one of the largest collections of Prairie Style buildings (particularly residences) outside the Midwest.{{Cite web |url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2010-aug-a-jacksonville-landmark-prairie-school-architecture |title=A Jacksonville Landmark: Prairie School Architecture |last=Davis |first=Ennis |date=2010-08-04 |website=Metro Jacksonville |access-date=May 6, 2016|df=mdy-all}} {{wide image|Aftermath of Great Fire of 1901.jpg|900px|align-cap=center|Bird's-eye view of the destruction left in the wake of the Great Fire of 1901}} ==See also== *[[Hotel Roosevelt fire]]: costly 1963 fire in downtown Jacksonville *[[History of Jacksonville, Florida]] *[[List of historic fires]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.floridamemory.com/photographiccollection/photo_exhibits/jacksonvillefire/ Photographic exhibit on the 1901 Great Fire, presented by the State Archives of Florida.] *[http://jaxhistory.com/greatfire2.htm Information about the fire from the Jacksonville Historical Society] *[http://www.firehouse.com/news/2001/5/3_greatfire.html 1901 "Great Fire" Remembered] *[http://web.uflib.ufl.edu/spec/pkyonge/jacksonville/fire.html An Artistic Description of a Gloomy Affair] {{coord missing|Jacksonville}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Great Fire Of 1901}} {{Infobox person | name = Kenneth E. Brailsford | image = Kenneth E Brailsford.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Niagara Falls, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Park City, Utah]] | nationality = American | alma_mater = | occupation = Founder & CEO of Zija International | years_active = | home_town = | spouse = Linda Hughes Brailsford | children = | website = {{URL|http://kenbrailsford.com/}} }} '''Kenneth E. Brailsford''' is an American entrepreneur, investor and philanthropist.{{cite news|last1=Allred|first1=Cathy|title=KEB wins Lehi Roller Mills bid, court approves sale|url=http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/north/lehi/keb-wins-lehi-roller-mills-bid-court-approves-sale/article_21115678-cd71-54f8-b1fb-b76b46e0659c.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Daily Herald|date=Aug 21, 2013}} He is known as a pioneer in the nutritional supplement and network marketing industry and considered the “Father of Herbal Encapsulation”.{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurship Lecture Series|url=https://www.uvu.edu/entrepreneurship/resources/lectures/fall-2015.html|website=Entrepreneurship Institute|accessdate=25 August 2017}} Brailsford was the first to commercially introduce herbs in capsule form when he co-founded [[Nature's Sunshine Products|Nature’s Sunshine]] in 1972.{{cite news|title=Industry Veteran Ken Brailsford, Founder of Zija, Pens Autobiography|url=http://directsellingnews.com/index.php/view/industry_veteran_ken_brailsford_founder_of_zija_pens_autobiography#.WaBfkYqQxBy|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Direct Selling News|date=November 12, 2015}} He later went on to found two more network marketing companies—Enrich International in 1985{{cite web|title=Enrich International, Inc. History|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/enrich-international-inc-history/|website=Funding Universe|accessdate=25 August 2017}} and Zija International in 2006, both of which are still in operation.{{cite news|title=Zija International Acquires XANGO|url=http://directsellingnews.com/index.php/view/zija_international_acquires_xango#.WaBj4YqQxBw|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Direct Selling News|date=May 10, 2017}} == Early life and education == Brailsford was born in 1944 in [[Niagara Falls, New York]], to Robert Earl and Freeda Webster Brailsford.{{cite news|title=Mission Presidents|url=http://www.ldschurchnewsarchive.com/articles/41151/Mission-presidents.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=LDS Church News Archive|date=January 12, 2002}} He served in the [[United States Army|US Army]] for two years after graduating from [[Brigham Young University]] with a degree in [[economics]] in 1969.{{cite web|last1=Nuyten|first1=Ted|title=Ken Brailsford – Founder Zija International Interview|url=https://www.businessforhome.org/2015/08/ken-brailsford-founder-zija-international-interview/|website=Business For Home|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Career == Brailsford co-founded [[Nature's Sunshine Products|Nature’s Sunshine]] in 1972 and served as President of the company from 1972-1979. After leaving Nature’s Sunshine, he went to work as a stockbroker for a short time, but then reemerged in the herbal industry once his non-compete agreement with Nature’s Sunshine had expired. Brailsford then went on to help launch Nature’s Labs Inc., later renamed Enrich International. He worked there from 1985-1997 and retired in 1997.{{cite news|title=Zija Founder Kenneth Brailsford Receives Outstanding Alumni Award|url=http://directsellingnews.com/index.php/view/zija_founder_kenneth_brailsford_receives_outstanding_alumni_award#.WaBsuoqQxBx|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Direct Selling News|date=September 29, 2015}} In 2004, his interest in [[Pharmacology|pharmacology]] led him to the [[Moringa oleifera|Moringa oleifera]] plant—a superfood prized for its high levels of vitamins, minerals, vital proteins, antioxidants and omega oils. In 2006, he founded Zija International to bring the benefits of Moringa to market. Brailsford has over 35 years in the [[Direct selling|Direct Sales]] industry. Brailsford owns a [[Private equity firm|private equity firm]], KEB Enterprises L.P., that manages other business [[Investment|investments]].{{cite web|title=About KEB Enterprises|url=http://www.kebenterprises.com/about/|website=KEB Enterprises|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Awards == [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Ernst and Young Entrepreneur of the Year]] (1994){{cite news|title=Orem Man Receives Entrepreneur Award|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/366516/OREM-MAN-RECEIVES-ENTREPRENEUR-AWARD.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=Deseret News|date=July 26, 1994}}
[[Utah Valley University|UVU]] Outstanding Alumni Award (2015)
Utah’s #1 Fastest-Growing Company Zija International (2014){{cite web|last1=Dunkley|first1=Nicole|title=Zija, CEO, Rodney Larsen Zija International Awarded As Utah’s #1 Growing Company|url=https://www.businessforhome.org/2014/09/zija-international-awarded-as-utahs-1-growing-company/|website=Business For Home|accessdate=25 August 2017}} == Personal Life == Ken married his college sweetheart, Linda Hughes Brailsford, and they are the parents of six children, twenty-four grandchildren, and seven great grandchildren. He and his wife currently live in [[Park City, Utah]].{{cite web|last1=Dunkley|first1=Nicole|title=Network Marketing Icon Ken Brailsford Pens Autobiography|url=https://www.businessforhome.org/2015/10/zija-internationals-ken-brailsford-pens-autobiography/|website=Business For Home|accessdate=25 August 2017}} Brailsford is a member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints]], sometimes nicknamed the Mormon or LDS Church. Among other assignments, Brailsford has served as a [[Bishop (Latter Day Saints)|bishop]], stake clerk, counselor in a [[Stake (Latter Day Saints)|stake presidency]], and from 2005 to 2008 as [[Mission president|president]] of the church’s Columbus [[South Carolina]] [[Mission (LDS Church)|mission]].{{cite news|title=New Mission Presidents|url=http://www.ldschurchnewsarchive.com/articles/47044/New-mission-presidents.html|accessdate=25 August 2017|work=LDS Church News|date=March 26, 2005}} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brailsford, Kenneth E.}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{for|the Donegal player|Kevin Rafferty (Gaelic footballer)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Kevin Rafferty |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = 1948 |birth_place = New York |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = Documentary films |occupation = [[Cinematographer]]
Film director
Film producer |nationality = American }} '''Kevin Rafferty''' is an American documentary film cinematographer, director, and producer, best known for his 1982 documentary ''[[The Atomic Cafe]]''.{{cite news|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/107401/Kevin-Rafferty/filmography|title=Kevin Rafferty|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=August 19, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.film.com/celebrities/kevin-rafferty/14597882|title=Kevin Rafferty credits|publisher=[[Film.com]]|accessdate=August 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208163405/http://www.film.com/celebrities/kevin-rafferty/14597882|archivedate=December 8, 2009|df=mdy-all}} ==Background== Rafferty studied architecture at [[Harvard]] and film at the [[California Institute of the Arts]]. {{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=100411486 |title=Tie To Win: Kevin Rafferty On 'Harvard Beats Yale' |date=February 12, 2009 |publisher=[[National Public Radio]] |accessdate=August 19, 2009}} He helped teach the craft of filmmaking to [[Michael Moore]] during the production of ''[[Roger & Me]]'' in 1989, and Moore has acknowledged Rafferty's influence on his own filmmaking. Rafferty teamed up with his brother [[Pierce Rafferty|Pierce]] and [[Jayne Loader]] [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFCyWdu71kw "Atomic Cafe" Producers on Late Night, March 10, 1982-YouTube] to produce the [[cult film|cult classic]] documentary film ''[[The Atomic Cafe]]''.{{cite web |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/film_and_history/v037/37.1wiener.pdf |title=Project MUSE – Film & History: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Film and Television Studies – The Omniscient Narrator and the Unreliable Narrator: The Case of Atomic Café |publisher=muse.jhu.edu |accessdate=August 15, 2009 |last=Wiener |first=Jon}} (requires login) He is the director, producer, editor and cinematographer of many documentary projects, including ''[[Blood in the Face]]'', ''[[The War Room]]'', ''Feed'', and ''The Last Cigarette.'' His latest project is ''[[Harvard Beats Yale 29-29]]''. {{cite web |url = http://www.ifc.com/news/2009/07/bell-jar-etude.php |title = A Bell Jar Etude |last = Atkinson |first = Michael |date = July 28, 2009 |publisher = [[Independent Film Channel|IFC]] |accessdate = August 19, 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090731150857/http://www.ifc.com/news/2009/07/bell-jar-etude.php |archivedate = July 31, 2009 |df = mdy-all }} Rafferty is a nephew of US former First Lady Barbara Bush, and a cousin of former US President George W. Bush.[http://www.democracynow.org/2010/9/6/michael_moore_on_his_life_his Goodman, Amy].''[[Democracy Now]]'', "Michael Moore on His Life, His Films and His Activism," September 6, 2010. Last accessed: February 20, 2011. ==Filmography== ===As director or producer=== *''[[Harvard Beats Yale 29-29]]'' (2008) *''Who Wants to Be President?'' (2000) *''The Last Cigarette'' (1999/I) *''Feed'' (1992) *''[[Blood in the Face]]'' (1991) *''[[Radio Bikini]]'' (1988) *''[[The Atomic Cafe]]'' (1982) *''Hurry Tomorrow'' (1975) ===As cinematographer=== *''Good Money'' (1996) *''[[The War Room]]'' (1993) *''[[Roger & Me]]'' (1989) ===As himself=== *''[[Manufacturing Dissent]]'' (2007) *''[[SexTV]]'' (2003) (TV) ==Reception== Thom Powers of ''Harvardwood'' writes that Rafferty is "renowned for his wit and fresh perspectives on American culture". {{cite news |url = http://www.harvardwood.org/events/event_details.asp?id=29966 |title = Harvardwood Heads To..."Harvard Beats Yale 29-29" at Toronto International Film Festival – Toronto |last = Powers |first = Thom |date = September 5, 2008 |publisher = Harvardwood |accessdate = August 19, 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110726141851/http://www.harvardwood.org/events/event_details.asp?id=29966 |archivedate = July 26, 2011 |df = mdy-all }} His various films have received positive reception. Of ''Hurry Tomorrow'', Rafferty's documentary indictment of a California State psychiatric hospital, Colin Bennet of ''[[The Age]]'' wrote "Its anger and courage are the kind that lead to reform".{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zYkQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1JIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4224,441098&dq=kevin-rafferty+documentary|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713014744/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zYkQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1JIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4224,441098&dq=kevin-rafferty+documentary|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 13, 2012|title=Cinema|last=Bennett|first=Colin|date=August 17, 1979|publisher=[[The Age]]|accessdate=August 20, 2009}} Michael Atkinson of ''[[Independent Film Channel|IFC]]'' calls Rafferty's latest, ''Harvard Beats Yale 29-29'', "a hypnotic pleasure," and ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' calls it an "engrossing documentary" which was "the best sports film we've seen in years", {{cite web |url = http://www.fastcompany.com/blog/very-short-list/very-short-list/under-pressure-what-long-strange-game-it-was-feng-shui-goes-out |title = What a long, strange game it was |publisher = [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |accessdate = August 19, 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091204025437/http://www.fastcompany.com/blog/very-short-list/very-short-list/under-pressure-what-long-strange-game-it-was-feng-shui-goes-out |archivedate = December 4, 2009 |df = mdy-all }} and Manhola Dargis of ''[[New York Times]]'' writes "while it seems absurd to include such a picayune event in the annals, the filmmaker Kevin Rafferty makes the case for remembrance and for the art of the story in his preposterously entertaining documentary ''Harvard Beats Yale 29-29".{{cite news|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2008/11/19/movies/19harv.html|title=Back in 1968, When a Tie Was No Tie|last=Dargis|first=Manhola|date=November 16, 2008|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=August 20, 2009}} ''The Atomic Cafe'' had received praise as one of the best Cold War movies of all time. [http://www.tasteofcinema.com/2016/the-25-best-movies-about-the-cold-war/2/ The 25 Best Movies About The Cold War ≪ Taste of Cinema ≪ Movie Reviews and Classic Movie Lists] [http://sensesofcinema.com/2004/cteq/atomic_cafe/ The Atomic Cafe·Senses of Cinema] ===Recognition=== *1991, nomination, Grand Jury Prize for ''Blood in the Face'' by [[Sundance Film Festival]] *1983, nomination, Flaherty Documentary Award for Best Documentary for ''The Atomic Cafe'' by [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/film/nominations/?year=1982|title=Robert Flaherty Award |publisher=[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]]|accessdate=August 20, 2009}} *2016, ''[[The Atomic Cafe]]'' selected to the [[National Film Registry]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0706268|name=Kevin Rafferty}} * [http://www.allmovie.com/artist/kevin-rafferty-107401/filmography Kevin Rafferty] at [[All Movie Guide]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rafferty, Kevin}} [[Category:Film producers from New York (state)]] [[Category:Film directors from New York City]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bush family]] [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:American documentary filmmakers]] [[Category:Collage filmmakers]] [[Category:Harvard Graduate School of Design alumni]] [[Category:California Institute of the Arts alumni]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox Newspaper | name = Kommersant | logo = [[File:Logo Kommersant.svg|175px]] | image = Kommersant.png | image_size = 251px | caption = Front page on 27 December 2010 | type = Daily [[newspaper]] | owners = [[Alisher Usmanov]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1909}}, {{start date and age|1989}} | language = [[Russian language|Russian]] | headquarters = [[Moscow]] | circulation = 120,000-130,000 (July 2013) | website = {{URL|http://www.kommersant.ru/}} }}
'''''Kommersant''''' ({{lang-ru|Коммерса́нтъ}}, {{IPA-ru|kəmʲɪrˈsant|IPA}}, ''The Businessman'', often shortened to '''[[Ъ]]''') is a nationally distributed daily newspaper published in [[Russia]] mostly devoted to politics and business. It is a leading liberal business broadsheet.<ref>{{cite news|title=The press in Russia|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4315129.stm|accessdate=29 November 2014|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=16 May 2008}}</ref> The TNS Media and NRS Russia certified July 2013 circulation of the daily was 120,000-130,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kommersant.ru/about/kommersant|title=Kommersant Website; (Russian)|year=2013|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref>
== History == The newspaper was initially published in 1909, and it was closed down following the [[Bolshevik]] seizure of power and the introduction of censorship in 1917.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
In 1989, with the onset of press freedom in Russia, ''Kommersant'' was re-established under the ownership of businessman and publicist [[Vladimir Yakovlev (journalist)|Vladimir Yakovlev]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presseurop.eu/en/content/source-profile/356511-kommersant|title=Kommersant; Presseurop (English)|work=Presseurop|year=2012|accessdate=13 April 2012}}</ref>
To make the point that the publication had outlasted the Soviet regime, "Kommersant" is spelled in Russian with a terminal [[Yer|hard sign]] (ъ) – a letter that is silent at the end of a word in modern Russian, and was thus largely abolished by the post-revolution [[Reforms of Russian orthography#The post-revolution reform|Russian spelling reform]]. This is played up in the Kommersant logo, which features a script hard sign at the end of somewhat more formal font. The newspaper also refers to itself or its redaction as “Ъ”.
In 1997, autos-to-Aeroflot mogul [[Boris Berezovsky (businessman)|Boris Berezovsky]] – a member of the former President Boris Yeltsin's 'family'<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/russia/article/0,,2056443,00.html/ ''Fortune made in Yeltsin era''] – ''Guardian'', 13 April 2007. Retrieved 24 July 2007.</ref> – bought the Kommersant publishing house, which included ''Kommersant-daily'', two serious weekly magazines (the political ''Kommersant-vlast'' (literally 'Power') and the financial ''[[Kommersant Dengi]]'' ('Money') – as well as entertainment magazines ''Domovoi'' and ''Avtopilot'' and ''Molotok'', a teen magazine, which later incurred the authorities' wrath.<ref>[http://english.pravda.ru/russia/kremlin/82774-1/ ''Prosecutors to save Russian teenagers from SMS pornography'' – ''Pravda'', 30 June 2006]. Retrieved 24 July 2007.</ref>
Berezovsky sacked ''Kommersant'''s director-general, Andrei Vassiliev, and editor-in-chief, Alexander Stukalin, on 14 July 2005<ref>[http://www.bu.edu/iscip/digest/vol10/ed1008.html Boston University publication, July 2005]. Retrieved 14 October 2007</ref> in a move widely seen as preparation for the 2008 [[Russian presidential election, 2008|Russian presidential elections]].
In January 2005, ''Kommersant'' published blank pages as a protest at a court ruling ordering it to publish a denial of a story about a crisis at [[Alfa-Bank]]. The sole article in the paper was this one, published upside down, on the front page. The headline of the article was "Full Plaintiff" (полный истец) which has little meaning, but rhymes with a [[Russian mat|Russian swear word]], meaning "complete disaster" ({{Lang-ru|[[Russian mat|полный пиздец]]|links=|translit=polniy pizdets}}).<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Полный истец|url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=543041|work=Kommersant| location=Moscow|date=31 January 2005|language= Russian|accessdate=24 August 2009}}</ref> The English version of the article was headed "Alfa-d Up".<ref>{{cite news|title=Alfa-d Up|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p543041/r_524/Alfa-d_Up/|work=Kommersant|location=Moscow|date=31 January 2005|accessdate=28 August 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606111951/http://www.kommersant.com/p543041/r_524/Alfa-d_Up/|archivedate=6 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Berezovsky sold the Kommersant publishing house to an old friend and business partner, Georgian fruit canner and opposition television station owner [[Badri Patarkatsishvili]], who was already chairman of the Kommersant company's board.<ref>[http://www.editorsweblog.org/print_newspapers/2006/02/russian_publishing_house_kommersant_gets.php/ ''Russian publishing house Kommersant gets a new owner'' – Editors Weblog, World Association of Newspapers, 28 February 2006 quoting ''Ekspert'' magazine]. Retrieved 24 July 2007.</ref> In August 2006, Patarkatsishvili sold his 100% stake in the Kommersant publishing house to [[Alisher Usmanov]],<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/10/GIPI.html/ ''Alisher Usmanov'', ''Forbes''] Retrieved 24 July 2007.</ref> head of Gazprom's Gazprominvestholding subsidiary.
After clashing with Usmanov, ''Kommersant'' editor-in-chief Vladislav Borodulin left the paper.<ref>[http://www.editorsweblog.org/newsrooms_and_journalism/2006/10/russia_kommersant_editor_quits.php ''Kommersant editor quits'' - World Association of Newspapers, quoting the Associated Press, 2 October 2006]. Retrieved 24 July 2007.</ref> "[Borodulin’s] decision to resign was not forced, but evidently they expressed different views on how the publishing house should be developed," said the group's commercial director. Andrei Vasilyev, appointed for a second stint at the helm of the daily – after a long run from 1999 to 2005– said ''Kommersant-daily'' had no intention of following any imposed policy, and added that the edition would carry articles that might not please the owner.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/russia/20061002/54450883.html ''New/old Kommersant editor vows to maintain line''- RIA Novosti, 2 October 2006]. Retrieved 24 July 2007</ref>
On 9 December 2008 the publication of articles in English ceased, and currently the Kommersant website has no English version. Since February 2009 ''Kommersant'' newspaper is printed and distributed in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kommersant.uk.com |title="Коммерсантъ" United Kingdom|work=Kommersant|accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref>
In 2015, the paper began hosting US-Russia Crosstalk, a joint initiative between ''Kommersant'' and the [[Valdai Discussion Club|Valdai Club]] in Russia, and ''[[The Washington Times]]'' and the [[Center for the National Interest]] in the United States, featuring foreign policy related discussion regarding relations between the two countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/us-russia-crosstalk/|title=U.S.-Russia Crosstalk - Washington Times|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|website=www.washingtontimes.com|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref>
==Court cases== In January 2000 ''Kommersant'' was found guilty of libel against Russian entrepreneur [[Alex Konanykhin]] and ordered to pay compensation of US$3,000,000.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://themoscowtimes.com/news/article/us-court-finds-kommersant-guilty-of-libel/267610.html|title= U.S. Court Finds Kommersant Guilty of Libel|work= The Moscow Times|date= 25 January 2000|accessdate= 13 January 2011|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120418214924/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/us-court-finds-kommersant-guilty-of-libel/267610.html|archivedate= 18 April 2012|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
In May 2009 a Russian MP and prominent businessman [[Oleg Mikheyev]] sued the ''Kommersant'' for $217 million, claiming that one of the newspaper's articles "spoiled of his bank so badly it had to be sold at disadvantageous price". The court dismissed the judicial proceeding due to jurisdictional issues.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.mosnews.com/money/2009/05/28/volgoprom/ |title=Russian MP sues business daily |work=Mosnews |date=28 May 2009 |accessdate=13 January 2011 }} </ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Russia|Journalism}}
* {{Interlanguage link multi|Kommersant FM|ru|3=Коммерсантъ FM}} a Russian [[news radio|news-radio]] station

page.title: List of companies founded by UC Berkeley alumni

revision.text:
This is a '''list of companies founded by [[University of California, Berkeley]] alumni''', including attendees who enrolled in degree-programs at Berkeley but did not eventually graduate. This list is not exhaustive, as it only includes notable [[Company|companies]] <!-- i.e. having articles on Wikipedia, but we don't reference Wikipedia within Wikipedia--> of which the founding and development history is well recorded by reliable sources. In particular, [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]] are listed with their owners in parentheses.
UC Berkeley has often been cited as one of the leading universities worldwide in producing entrepreneurs and attracting funding for [[Startup company|start-up companies]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://news.berkeley.edu/story_jump/in-startup-sweepstakes-its-cal-vs-stanford/|title=In startup sweepstakes, it’s Cal vs. Stanford|date=2016-09-09|work=Berkeley News|access-date=2017-11-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.graphicsprings.com/founders-funding-and-exit-ranking-usa|title=Founders Funding And Exit Ranking Usa {{!}} GraphicSprings|work=Founders Funding And Exit Ranking Usa {{!}} GraphicSprings|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2013/08/18/uc-berkeley-third-largest-producer-of-entrepreneurs-report-says/|title=UC Berkeley third-largest producer of entrepreneurs, report says {{!}} The Daily Californian|date=2013-08-18|work=The Daily Californian|access-date=2017-11-23|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/uc-berkeley-no-1-global-entrepreneurship|title=UC Berkeley is No. 1 in global entrepreneurship|date=2016-09-16|work=University of California|access-date=2017-11-23|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/research/university-entrepreneurship-report/|title=The University Entrepreneurship Report – Alumni of Top Universities Rake in $12.6 Billion Across 559 Deals|date=2012-10-29|work=CB Insights Research|access-date=2017-11-23|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://readwrite.com/2012/12/03/one-university-to-rule-them-all-stanford-tops-startup-list/|title=One University To Rule Them All: Stanford Tops Startup List – ReadWrite|date=2012-12-03|work=ReadWrite|access-date=2017-11-23|language=en-US}}</ref> Its alumni and faculty have founded a large number of companies, and its degrees are among the most valuable in [[Silicon Valley]].<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://executive.berkeley.edu/thought-leadership/press-release/entrepreneurs-and-startups-uc-berkeley|title=Entrepreneurs and Startups at UC Berkeley {{!}} executive.berkeley.edu|website=executive.berkeley.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vcresearch.berkeley.edu/excellence/innovation-and-entrepreneurship|title=Innovation and Entrepreneurship {{!}} Research UC Berkeley|website=vcresearch.berkeley.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2013/12/09/silicon-valleys-top-10-most-lucrative.html|title=Silicon Valley's top 10 most lucrative degrees: where to go and what to major in to get the most money|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-22}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Industry/Startups/startup.html|title=EECS Entrepreneurial Startups {{!}} EECS at UC Berkeley|website=www2.eecs.berkeley.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref> According to [[PitchBook Data|PitchBook]], from 2006 to 2017, Berkeley produced 1,089 company founders as alumni or current students, second only to [[Stanford University]] in the world; and these founders created 961 companies, more than any other university in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.pitchbook.com/website/files/pdf/PitchBook_Universities_Report_2017-2018_Edition.pdf|title=Universities Report: The top 50 universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs (2017–2018)|last=|first=|date=|website=Pitchbook|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.pitchbook.com/pdf/PitchBook_Universities_Report_2016-2017_Edition.pdf|title=Universities Report: Top 50 universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs (2016–2017)|last=|first=|date=|website=Pitchbook|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In this list, founders of a company which [[merged]] with other companies to form a new company are counted as founders of the new company. However, founders of a company which later dissolved into several successor companies are ''not'' counted as founders of those successor companies; this same rule applies to [[Spin-off (corporate)|spin-off companies]]. Finally, a defunct company is a company that had stopped functioning completely (e.g., [[Bankruptcy|bankrupt]]) without dissolving, merging or being [[Acquisitions|acquired]].
== Top companies by revenues ==
=== Fortune Global 500 (2017) === This list shows companies in [[Fortune Global 500|''Fortune Global 500'']] founded or co-founded by UC Berkeley alumni. The cut-off revenue for 2017 ''Fortune Global 500'' companies is $21,609M in 2016.<ref name=":19" /> {| class="wikitable sortable" ! !Company !Region !Fortune Global 500 (2017)<ref name=":19">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/global500/list/|title=Fortune Global 500 List 2017: See Who Made It|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> !Revenue in US$ Millions (2016)<ref name=":19" /> !Type !Category !Year Founded !Comments |- |1 |[[Apple Inc.|Apple]] |[[United States]] |9 |215,639 |Public |Technology |1976 | |- |2 |[[SoftBank Group|Softbank Group]] |[[Japan]] |72 |82,892 |Public |[[Conglomerate (company)|Conglomerate]] |1981 | |- |3 |[[Intel]] |United States |144 |59,387 |Public |[[Semiconductor]] |1968 | |- |4 |[[American International Group]] ([[AIG]]) |United States |175 |52,367 |Public |[[Finance]] |1919 | |- |5 |[[Morgan Stanley]]* |United States |267 |37,949 |Public |Finance |1924 ([[Dean Witter Reynolds#Dean Witter & Co. (1924-1978)|Dean Witter & Co.]]) | |} <nowiki>*:</nowiki> <sub>Merger of different companies, at least one of which was founded by UC Berkeley alumni.</sub>

'''Majid Al Futtaim''' ([[Arabic]]: ماجد الفطيم) is an [[Emiratis|Emirati]] billionaire businessman, the founder, owner and president of the [[Majid Al Futtaim Group]], an Emirati real estate and retail conglomerate, with projects in Asia and Africa. As of March 2017, Al Futtaim's net worth is estimated by ''[[Forbes]]'' at US$10.9 billion, the second richest individual in the Middle East.
==Early life== Majid Al Futtaim is the brother in-law of fellow billionaire [[Abdulla Al Futtaim]], the head of the [[Al-Futtaim Group]], from whom he is estranged.<ref name=Forbes/> [[File:MajidFuttaimSheikhRashid.png|thumb|left|Majid Al Futtaim with Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed]] It currently spans 15 international markets and employs over 33,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Website|url=http://www.majidalfuttaim.com/about-us/overview/who-we-are/|accessdate=9 January 2017}}</ref>
==Career== He is the owner and president of [[Majid Al Futtaim Group]], which he founded in 1992 after splitting the Al Futtaim empire with his cousin.<ref name=Bloomberg>{{cite web|title=Majid Al Futtaim|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=28400444&privcapId=22690740|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref>
According to [[Forbes]], Al Futtaim has a net worth of $5 billion, as of February 2016.<ref name=Forbes/> In July 2013, Forbes named him as the richest entrepreneur from the UAE.<ref>Neuhof, Florian. [http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/economics/majid-al-futtaim-with-3-6bn-named-richest-uae-businessman "Majid Al Futtaim, with $3.6bn, named richest UAE businessman"], 'The National', 15 April 2013. Accessed 28 October 2015.</ref>
=== Notable buildings === His company's most notable properties include the [[Mall of the Emirates]], complete with an indoor ski slope, as well as the [[Mall of Egypt]] that was planned to open in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=#270 Majid Al Futtaim & family|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/majid-al-futtaim/}}</ref>
==Personal life== Al Futtaim is married and lives in Dubai.<ref name=Forbes/> His son Tariq Al Futtaim also works for the [[Majid Al Futtaim Group]].<ref name=Forbes/>
Al Futtaim owns the yacht ''Quattroelle'', built by [[Lurssen]] in 2013 for [[Michael Lee-Chin]], who sold it in 2014. It has a crew of 29.<ref name=Superyachtfan>{{cite web|title=Motor Yacht Quattroelle|url=http://www.superyachtfan.com/superyacht/superyacht_quattroelle.html|website=Superyachtfan|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref>
