{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {{infobox book | name = Start-up Nation: The Story of Israel's Economic Miracle | italic title = force | translator = | image = Start-up Nation.jpg | caption = | author = [[Dan Senor]] and [[Saul Singer]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = | publisher = [[Twelve (publisher)|Twelve]] | release_date = November 4, 2009 | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = 320 | isbn = 978-0-446-54146-6 | preceded_by = }} '''''Start-up Nation: The Story of Israel's Economic Miracle''''' is a 2009 book by [[Dan Senor]] and [[Saul Singer]] about the [[economy of Israel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Saul Singer interview on Startup Camel Podcast about the challenges Israel is facing as a global innovation leader.|url=http://startupcamel.com/ep-30-saul-singer-startup-nation|accessdate=28 February 2015|publisher=Startup Camel}}</ref> It examines how Israel, a 60-year-old nation with a population of 7.1 million, was able to reach such economic growth that "at the start of 2009, some 63 Israeli companies were listed on the [[NASDAQ]], more than those of any other foreign country."<ref name=WSJ/>
In 2010, ''Start-up Nation'' was ranked fifth on the business [[bestseller]] list of ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/03/books/bestseller/besthardbusiness.html NYT Hardcover Business Best Sellers]</ref> It also reached ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' bestseller list.<ref>[http://www.cjp.org/local_includes/downloads/46889.pdf The Massachusetts-Israel Economic Relationship]</ref>
==Book overview== The [[Council on Foreign Relations]] states in its publisher's blurb for the book that ''Start-up Nation'' addresses the question: "How is it that Israel—a country of 7.1 million people, only sixty years old, surrounded by enemies, in a constant state of war since its founding, with no natural resources—produces more start-up companies than large, peaceful, and stable nations like Japan, China, India, Korea, Canada, and the United Kingdom?"<ref name=CFR/> ''[[The Economist]]'' notes that Israel now has more high-tech [[Startup company|start-ups]] and a larger [[Venture capital in Israel|venture capital industry]] per capita than any other country in the world. The success of Israel's high-tech sector over the past two decades has attracted recent attention from business journalists and ''The Economist'' describes ''Start-up Nation'' as the most notable of a "growing pile" of books on the subject.<ref name=Economist/>
In their attempt to explain Israel's success in this area, Senor and Singer discard "the argument from ethnic or religious exceptionalism, dismissing 'unitary Jewishness' or even individual talent as major reasons for Israel's high-tech success" and analyze two major factors that, in the authors' opinion, contribute most to Israel's economic growth. Those factors are [[Conscription in Israel|mandatory military service]] and [[Aliyah|immigration]].<ref name=CFR/>
The authors argue that a major factor for Israel's economic growth can be found in the culture of the [[Israel Defense Forces]], in which service is mandatory for most young Israelis. The authors believe that IDF service provides potential entrepreneurs with the opportunities to develop a wide array of skills and contacts. They also believe that IDF service provides experience exerting responsibility in a relatively un-hierarchical environment where creativity and intelligence are highly valued.<ref name=oreilly/> IDF soldiers "have minimal guidance from the top, and are expected to improvise, even if this means breaking some rules. If you're a junior officer, you call your higher-ups by their first names, and if you see them doing something wrong, you say so."<ref name=WSJ/> Neither [[Military rank|rank]]s nor ages matter much "when taxi drivers can command millionaires and 23-year-olds can train their uncles," and "Israeli forces regularly vote to oust their unit leaders."<ref name=Forbes/>
The book also dwells at length on immigration and its role in Israel's economic growth: "Immigrants are not averse to start from scratch. They are by definition risk-takers. A nation of immigrants is a nation of entrepreneurs. From survivors of the Holocaust to Soviet refuseniks through the Ethiopian Jews, the State of Israel never ceased to be a land of immigration: 9 out of 10 Jewish Israelis today are immigrants or descendants of immigrants the first or second generation. This specific demographic, causing fragmentation of community that still continues in the country, is nevertheless a great incentive to try their luck, to take risks because immigrants have nothing to lose."<ref name=inaglobal/>
Additional factors cited by the authors include a sense of dissatisfaction with the current state of affairs, a culture where individuals frequently tinker with technology, and government policies friendly to start-ups.<ref name=oreilly/>
Using stories and anecdotes, the book provides examples of Israel's technological and medical achievements, among them "the Israeli innovations that made possible Google Suggest, the list of suggestions that appear instantly in menu form as you type a search request, the capsule endoscopy, a miniature camera embedded in a pill so that 18 photos per second can be wirelessly and painlessly transmitted from gastrointestinal tracts."<ref name="The Weekly Standard"/>
While the book describes Israel's many successes in technological innovation, it also attempts to address, in the words of one reviewer, why Israel still lacks its own [[Nokia]], [[Samsung]], or [[IBM]]. According to the book's authors, this is partly because Israeli startups tend to be bought up by large foreign companies and partly because Israeli business has thus far failed to develop the kind of mature management culture needed to run such companies.<ref name=Monitor/>
Senor and Singer interviewed over 100 people to write the book, among them leading Israeli venture investors including key players in [[Google]], [[Intel]], and [[Cisco]]; and historians, U.S. military leaders, and Israeli heads of state.<ref>Senor and Singer, pp. 240-241.</ref> Their conclusion is that "while Israel has much to learn from the world, the world has much to learn from Israel."<ref>Senor and Singer, p. 236.</ref>
==Authors==
Dan Senor is a former foreign policy official in the [[United States]] government. He served as chief spokesmen for the [[Coalition Provisional Authority]] in [[Iraq]] and now advises venture capital firms. Saul Singer is a columnist and former [[editorial page]] editor for ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''.<ref name=WSJ/><ref name="The Washington Post"/>
==Critical reception==
===Praise=== Jon Rosen OF ''[[USA Today]]'' believes that the book is written from an Israeli perspective and may irk those with reservations about Israeli foreign policy, but it is still an accomplishment, "not simply for exposing the roots of Israel's success, but by showing what the Israeli case might teach the rest of the world."<ref name="USA Today"/> In ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', [[James K. Glassman]] says that "the greatest strength of ''Start-up Nation'' is not analysis but anecdote. The authors tell vivid stories of entrepreneurial success, such as that of Shai Agassi, the son of an Iraqi immigrant to Israel, with his electric-automobile technology, now in the process of creating 'Car 2.0.'"<ref name=WSJ/>
''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' states that "the authors ground their analysis in case studies and interviews with some of Israel's most brilliant innovators to make this a rich and insightful read not just for business leaders and policy makers but for anyone curious about contemporary Israeli culture."<ref name="Publishers Weekly"/>
In ''[[The Economic Times]]'', [[R Gopalakrishnan]] writes that the use of [[Hebrew]] expressions makes the book "alive and eminently-readable."<ref name="The Economic Times"/> Besides ''chutzpah'', the authors use the word ''bitzua'', which roughly means "getting things done." Another Hebrew expression used in the book is ''rosh gadol'', literally "big head", which could be translated "can-do and responsible attitude with scant respect for the limitations of formal authority." Gopalakrishnan concludes that the ideas demonstrated in the book "are highly relevant for innovation capability in general, but for India, especially at this juncture."<ref name="The Economic Times"/>
[[David Horovitz]] of ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' says that conclusions of ''Start-up Nation'' find confirmation in the real world, such as how the life of Congresswoman [[Gabrielle Giffords]] was saved when an emergency medical team applied a revolutionary elasticized bandage developed in Israel to staunch her head wounds.<ref name=TJP/>
A review in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' says that "the book weaves together colorful stories of Israeli technological triumphs" such as the story of [[Shvat Shaked]], who "founded a cybersecurity firm with his old buddy from Army intelligence and had the chutzpah to bet a top executive at PayPal, the online commerce company owned by eBay, that his few dozen engineers could beat PayPal's thousands in developing secure online software."<ref name="The Washington Post"/> The review also states that the authors could have done a better job drawing "straight lines between their theories about Israel's success and these case studies".<ref name="The Washington Post"/>
Maureen Farrell of ''[[Forbes]]'' was disappointed that the authors mostly ignored the effects of U.S. foreign aid, but says the book "is worth reading to understand not just Israel's history but the history of capitalism and innovation."<ref name=Forbes/>
===Criticism=== Ruth Schuster, reviewing the book for ''[[Haaretz]]'', feels that it is "tarnished by a jarring, tub-thumping patriotism."<ref name=haaretzrev /> A review in ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' notes that "critics say that the story behind how a country of 7 million has more Nasdaq-listed companies than Europe is more complex than Singer and Senor paint it to be."<ref name=Monitor/>
Economist [[Yusuf Mansur]], writing in the ''[[Jordan Times]]'', argues that two of the factors to which Senor and Singer attribute Israel's success, the IDF and Soviet-Jewish immigration, have only been sustainable because of the foreign aid that Israel receives from the United States and private sources. Mansur also faults the authors for suggesting that the disparity between entrepreneurship in Israel's Arab and Jewish sectors is rooted in the exemption of Arabs from military service rather than what Mansour perceives to be "the discriminatory policies of Israel against its Arab citizens," particularly in education and the labor market.<ref name=jordantimes>[http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=25450 "Financing 'the start-up nation'"], ''Jordan Times'', April 6, 2010.</ref>
Gal Beckerman, writing in ''[[The Forward]]'' magazine, observes that the book "presents Israel in an extremely positive light as a bastion of entrepreneurial spirit and technological achievement. It skirts a discussion of the conflict with the Palestinians, or even the wealth inequality within Israel, thereby dovetailing nicely with recent public relations efforts by Israel to shift attention away from its problems and toward its achievements."<ref name=beckerman>Beckerman, Gal: [http://www.forward.com/articles/126843/ "Senor Decides Against Running for Senate, Citing Family and Business"], ''[[The Forward]]'', March 24, 2010.</ref>
==Impact== Journalists and policymakers in several countries have recommended ''Start-up Nation'' as a useful guide for promoting entrepreneurship. A review of the book in ''[[The Irish Times]]'' calls on Ireland to follow Israel's model.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/weekend/2010/0626/1224273322693.html What Ireland has to learn from Israel's high tech companies]</ref> [[Andrius Kubilius]], the prime minister of Lithuania, has cited ''Start-up Nation'' as his favorite book.<ref>[http://english.themarker.com/startup-nation-without-physics-teachers-1.333940 Startup nation without physics teachers], [[Haaretz]]</ref> Yrjö Ojasaar, managing partner of Solon Partners, an executive consulting and angel investor company in Estonia, says "there is much to be learned from the Israeli experience of venture capital incubation through building incentives for privatization."<ref>[http://www.solonpartners.com/?p=961 Solon Partners: Start-up Nation. The Story of Israel’s Economic Miracle]</ref> CNN's [[Fareed Zakaria]] called ''Start-up Nation'' "a book every single Arab businessman, Arab bureaucrat, and Arab politician should read."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/world/2009/11/09/gps.book.of.the.week.cnn |title=Book of the Week |work=[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]] |publisher=CNN |date=November 19, 2009 |accessdate=May 4, 2011 }}</ref> The book is cited as a handbook of "classic economics." It teaches small businesses "how effective a cohesive team can be, especially when that team places an emphasis on [[chutzpah]] first."<ref>[http://smallbiztrends.com/2009/12/start-up-nation-business-lessons-from-israel.html Start-Up Nation: Business Lessons from Israel]</ref>
Palestinian Prime Minister [[Salam Fayyad]] reportedly keeps a copy of ''Start-up Nation'' on his desk as a source of inspiration for the [[West Bank]]'s own burgeoning technology industry.<ref>{{cite news |title=Israeli Technology Companies Turn to West Bank for Outsourcing |author=Gwen Ackerman |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/israeli-technology-companies-turn-to-west-bank-for-outsourcing.html |newspaper=Bloomberg News |date=March 15, 2011 |accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Economy of Israel]] *[[Israeli inventions and discoveries]] *[[Science and technology in Israel]] *[[Silicon Wadi]] *[[List of Israeli companies quoted on the Nasdaq]] *[[List of multinationals with research and development centres in Israel]] *[https://www.startupnationcentral.org/ Start-Up Nation Central] *[[Venture capital in Israel]]

[[Contributing Property]] | designated_other2_abbr = DLMKHD | designated_other2_color = #F5DEB3 | designated_other2_date = October 6, 1975{{cite web|title=West End Historic District|url=http://dallascityhall.com/departments/sustainabledevelopment/historicpreservation/Documents/West%20End%20Report.pdf|author=Staff|date=August 4, 2016|page=3|publisher=Department of Urban Planning, City of Dallas|access-date=August 2, 2018}} | designated_other2_number = [http://dallascityhall.com/departments/sustainabledevelopment/historicpreservation/Pages/landmark_districts.aspx H/2] ([[West End Historic District (Dallas)|West End HD]]) | designated_other2_num_position = bottom }} }} [[File:Texas historical marker for the Texas School Book Depository.jpg|thumb|Texas historical marker for the Texas School Book Depository]] The '''Texas School Book Depository''', now known as the '''Dallas County Administration Building''', is a seven-floor building facing [[Dealey Plaza]] in [[Dallas|Dallas, Texas]], [[United States]]. The building is most notable as the vantage point of the [[assassination of John F. Kennedy]] on November 22, 1963. An employee, [[Lee Harvey Oswald]], allegedly shot and killed Kennedy from a sixth floor window on the building's southeastern corner. The structure is a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark]]. It is located at 411 Elm Street on the northwest corner of Elm and [[Houston Street (Dallas)|North Houston Street]]s, at the western end of [[downtown Dallas]]. ==Early history== The site of the building was originally owned by [[John Neely Bryan]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/jdt01 |title=The Handbook of Texas Online: Texas School Book Depository |author=Texas State Historical Association |authorlink=Texas State Historical Association |year=2012 |publisher=Texas State Historical Association |work=Tshaonline.org |accessdate=April 17, 2012}} During the 1880s, Maxime Guillot operated a wagon shop on the property. In 1894, the Rock Island Plow Company bought the land, and four years later constructed a five-story building for its Texas division, the Southern Rock Island Plow Company. In 1901, the building was hit by lightning and nearly burned to the ground. It was rebuilt in 1902 in the Commercial [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival]] style, and expanded to seven stories. In 1937 the property was acquired by the Carraway Byrd Corporation, and after the company defaulted on the loan, it was bought at public auction July 4, 1939 by [[D. Harold Byrd]].Jerry Organ (2000). [http://mcadams.posc.mu.edu/organ4.htm "Murder Perch to Museum"]. [[Marquette University]]. Under Byrd's ownership the building remained empty until 1940, when it was leased by a grocery wholesaler, the [[Sexton Foods|John Sexton & Co.]] Sexton Foods used this location as the branch office for sales, manufacturing and distribution warehouse for the south and southwest United States. In November 1961, Sexton Foods moved to a modern distribution facility located at 650 Regal Row Dallas; by then the building was known locally as the Sexton Building. Refurbishment after Sexton's departure saw the addition on the first four floors of partitions, carpeting, air conditioning and a new passenger elevator. ==Assassination of John F. Kennedy== {{main|Assassination of John F. Kennedy}} In 1963, the building was in use as a multi-floor [[warehouse]] providing the storage of school [[textbook]]s and other related materials as well as an order-fulfillment center by the privately owned [[Texas School Book Depository Company]]. Some time after the company had moved in, it was found that the upper floors had sustained oil damage from items stored there by the previous tenant, a wholesaler grocer. To protect the company's books (stored in cardboard boxes) from oil seeping up from the floor, a process to cover the floors with plywood had begun. Immediately before the President Kennedy's visit to Dallas, work on the west side of the sixth floor had started, "leaving the whole scene in disarray, with stock shifted as far as the east wall, and stacks in between piled unusually high." On November 22, 1963, [[Lee Harvey Oswald]], a 24-year-old former [[USMC|U.S. Marine]] who was working as a temporary employee at the building, fired three shots from a sixth floor window at the presidential motorcade, [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|killing]] [[President of the United States|President]] [[John F. Kennedy]]. ===Second building=== In addition to its building at Elm and Houston, the Texas School Book Depository Company maintained a second warehouse at 1917 Houston. Several blocks north of the main building, the short four-story structure was well removed from the parade route, half-hidden on an unpaved section of Houston. Oswald's supervisor, Roy Truly, told the Warren Commission that he had had the option to assign Oswald to either building on his first day at work. "I might have sent Oswald to work [there]... Oswald and another fellow reported for work on the same day [October 15] and I needed one of them for the depository building. I picked Oswald."{{Cite book |title=Reclaiming History: The Assassination of President John F. Kennedy |last=Bugliosi |first=Vincent |authorlink=Vincent Bugliosi |year=2007 |publisher=W.W. Norton |location=New York |isbn=978-0-393-04525-3 |page=1455 }} This second building was eventually destroyed to make way for the [[Texas State Highway Spur 366|Woodall Rodgers Freeway]]. ==Later years== During his two terms as mayor of Dallas, [[Wes Wise]] guided Dallas out from under the cloud of the assassination and at the same time saved the Texas School Book Depository from imminent destruction, preserving it for further research into the president's murder.Douglass, James W. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NfvkfM8IbBsC&pg=PA45&dq=JFK+and+the+Unspeakable+since+roosevelt&hl=de&sa=X&ei=mlFnT4m2NYHP4QSchOTwBw&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=JFK%20and%20the%20Unspeakable%20since%20roosevelt&f=false JFK and the Unspeakable. Why he died and why it matters]''. Maryknoll, NY, Orbis Books, 2008, p. 295-298. {{ISBN|978-1-57075-755-6}} The Texas School Book Depository Company moved out in 1970 and the building was sold at auction to [[Aubrey Mayhew]], a [[Nashville, Tennessee]] music producer and collector of Kennedy memorabilia, by the owner D. H. Bard. In 1972, ownership reverted to Bard, and the building was purchased in 1977 by the government of [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas County]]. After renovating the lower five floors of the building for use as county government offices, the Dallas County Administration Building was dedicated on March 29, 1981.{{Cite book|title=Assassination and commemoration : JFK, Dallas, and the Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza|last=Fagin|first=Stephen|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=2013|isbn=9780806143583|location=Norman|pages=74}} On President's Day 1989, the sixth floor opened to the public (for an admission charge) as the [[Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza|Sixth Floor Museum]] of assassination-related exhibits. On President's Day 2002, the seventh-floor gallery opened.{{Cite book|title=Seventy-Seven Museum Gems|last=Young|first=Jan|publisher=Lulu.com|year=2006|isbn=136544399X|location=|pages=57|oclc=980689344}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jfk.org/wp-content/uploads/History_of_411_Elm.pdf|title=History of 411 Elm The Texas School Book Depository and the Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza|last=|first=|date=August 2013|website=JFK.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}} The gallery opened on February 18, 2002 with the exhibit: "The Pulitzer Prize Photographs: Capture the Moment".{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/stories/2002/02/11/daily26.html|title=Sixth Floor Museum plans exhibit for 7th floor expansion|last=|first=|date=February 13, 2002|website=Dallas Business Journal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}} A $2.5 million renovation turned the storage area on the seventh floor into a new gallery space for the museum. Other exhibits that have hung in the space include the works Andy Warhol.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/03/03/arts/mixing-tragedy-with-art-in-dallas-book-depository-site-now-includes-gallery.html|title=Mixing Tragedy With Art In Dallas; Book Depository Site Now Includes Gallery|last=Kinzer|first=Stephen|date=March 3, 2003|website=The New York Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/news/2010/11/22/47-years-after-jfk-assassination-sixth-floor-museum-adapts-to-new-era|title=47 years after JFK assassination, Sixth Floor Museum adapts to new era|last=Flick|first=David|date=November 2010|website=Dallas Morning News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 30, 2018}} On May 4, 2010, burglars attempted to steal a safe from the Sixth Floor Museum, but fled when "they were confronted by a security guard," leaving the unopened safe suspended from a [[winch]] on the back of a truck.{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/crime/stories/050510dnmetsixthfloor.1500a362.html|title=Theft of safe at Sixth Floor Museum visitors center thwarted|date=May 5, 2010|first=Jason|last=Trahan|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News}} ==See also== {{Portal|NRHP|Texas}} *[[List of National Historic Landmarks in Texas]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings {{infobox_person | name = Theodore Havemeyer | image = Theodore Havemeyer.JPG | birth_name = Theodore Augustus Havemeyer | birth_date = May 17, 1839 | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1897|04|26|1839|05|17}} | death_place = New York City, New York, U.S. | education = [[Betts Academy|Mr. Betts' School]] | alma_mater = | parents = Frederick Christian Havemeyer Jr.
Sarah Louise Henderson | spouse = {{marriage|Emily de Loosey
|1865|1897|reason=his death}} | children = 9 | relations = ''See'' [[Havemeyer family]] }} '''Theodore Augustus Havemeyer''' (May 17, 1839 – April 26, 1897) was an American businessman who was the first president of the [[U.S. Golf Association]] and co-founder of the [[Newport Country Club]], host to both the first [[United States Amateur Championship (golf)|U.S. Amateur]] and the first [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] in 1895.[https://books.google.com/books?id=_QFXDK6XmeQC&source=gbs_navlinks_s Golf and the American country club] by Richard J. Moss (University of Illinois Press, 2001) ==Early life== Havemeyer was born in New York City on May 17, 1839. He was the eldest son of three children born to Frederick Christian Havemeyer Jr. (1807-1891), and Sarah Louise ([[née]] Henderson) Havemeyer (1812-1851). His mother died in 1851 and he was then raised with the help of his grandmothers, Mary Osborne Henderson and Catharine Billiger Havemeyer, and his oldest sister, Mary Havemeyer. The family lived in a house at 193 West 14th Street,{{cite web|title=Trow's New York City Directory, 1854/1855|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.hnfij4;view=1up;seq=331|accessdate=24 September 2016}} Note: 14th Street was renumbered in 1869. in what was then the northern frontier of New York City. Theodore studied at Mr. Betts' School ([[Betts Academy]]) in [[Stamford, Connecticut]].{{sfnp|Havemeyer|2010|p=5-7, 17}} Theodore's grandfather, a [[German people|German]] immigrant, came to the United States in 1802 and started a sugar refining company with his brother and Theodore's father started his own firm, Havemeyer & Elder.{{cite news|title=DEATH OF T. A. HAVEMEYER; Vice President of the American Sugar Refining Company and a Man of Large Affairs. WAS BAPTIZED WHEN DYING Called for a Priest and Was Received into the Catholic Church -- To be Buried from the Cathedral -His Notable Career.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/04/27/archives/death-of-ta-havemeyer-vice-president-of-the-american-sugar-refining.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 April 1897}} ==Career== Theodore became an apprentice in his father's firm and later was made a partner working with his brother [[Henry Osborne Havemeyer]]. After traveling to Germany and England, in search of new advances in the sugar refining trade, Theodore constructed "one of the most modern sugar refineries in the world."Henry Bischoff and Mitchell Kahn, ''From Pioneer Settlement to Suburb, A History of Mahwah, New Jersey, 1700-1976'', (South Brunswick and New York: A. S. Barnes and Company, 1979), p. 138. Theodore Havemeyer was also the Austro-Hungarian Consul-General in New York City for twenty-five years, up until 1895. He became president of the New York Golf Club and the first president United States Golf Association, as well.{{cite news|title=T.A. HAVEMEYER ON GOLF; RAPID GROWTH OF THE GAME IN THIS COUNTRY. Danger in Too Many Clubs in One Locality -- Against Expensive Clubhouses to the Detriment of the Sport.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/01/10/archives/ta-havemeyer-on-golf-rapid-growth-of-the-game-in-this-country.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 January 1897}}{{cite news|title=HE SUCCEEDS MR. HAVEMEYER.; Mr. Curtis Now President of the Golf Association.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/06/11/archives/he-succeeds-mr-havemeyer-mr-curtis-now-president-of-the-golf.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 June 1897}} Havemeyer co-founded the Newport Country Club, U.S. Amateur Championship and U.S. Open. The U.S. Amateur trophy, the Havemeyer Cup, is currently named in his honor. His portrait was painted by the Swiss-born American artist [[Adolfo Müller-Ury]], one is now in the New York State Museum at Albany; Müller-Ury also painted in 1891 a huge portrait of his wife Emilie de Loosey Havemeyer ([[Preservation Society of Newport County, Rhode Island]] (at [[Rosecliff]]). ===Estates=== The family owned many estates including, a town house on [[Madison Avenue]] in New York City, a mansion on Bellevue Avenue in [[Newport, Rhode Island]], and 500 acres in [[Mahwah, New Jersey]], called Mountain Side Farm. 300 acres of the Mahwah estate is currently the campus of [[Ramapo College of New Jersey]]. The house that Havemeyer and his family lived in is now the home to the college's President and the house that Havemeyer had built for his daughter Lillie, as part of the estate, currently stands as the Administration Building for the college.Henry Bischoff and Mitchell Kahn, ''From Pioneer Settlement to Suburb, A History of Mahwah, New Jersey, 1700-1976'', (South Brunswick and New York: A. S. Barnes and Company, 1979), p. 142. ==Personal life== In 1862, Havemeyer married Emily de Loosey (1844–1914), daughter of Chevalier Charles F. de Loosey, the Austrian Consul to New York.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=MRS. T. A. HAVEMEYER DEAD.; End Comes in Switzerland on Eve of Sailing for This Country.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1914/05/04/archives/mrs-t-a-havemeyer-dead-end-comes-in-switzerland-on-eve-of-sailing.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 May 1914}} Together, they had nine children, five daughters and four sons. * Nathalie Ida Blanche Havemeyer (1864–1900), who married John Mayer * Emily Blanche Havemeyer (b. 1865), who married Edward Clarkson Potter * [[Charles Frederick Havemeyer]] (1867–1898), who married [[Camilla Woodward Moss Havemeyer|Camilla Woodward Moss]] and became well known in New York Society.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}} * Theodore Augustus Havemeyer, Jr. (b. 1868){{cite news|title=T. A. HAVEMEYER, 2D, WEDS.; Former Fiance of Miss Bispham Marries Miss MacLean in Vancouver|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1915/08/27/archives/t-a-havemeyer-2d-weds-former-fiance-of-miss-bispham-marries-miss.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 August 1915}} * Blanche Maximillian Havemeyer (1871–1958), who married William Butler Duncan, Jr. * Marie Ida Pauline Havemeyer (1872–1925), who married Perry Tiffany (1866–1928) and H. F. Godfrey * Henry Osborne Havemeyer II, who became a major financier of [[Stephen Birch]] and the future [[Kennecott Copper Company]].{{Cite book |author=Charles Caldwell Hawley |title=A Kennecott Story |publisher=The University of Utah Press |year=2014 |page=33}} * Theodora Havemeyer (1878–1945), who married Admiral [[Cameron Winslow]] (1854–1932) * Frederick Christian Havemeyer (b. 1879), who married Lillie Harriman (b. 1870), daughter of [[Oliver Harriman|Oliver H. Harriman]].{{cite book|title=The World Almanac and Book of Facts|date=1911|publisher=Press Publishing Company (The New York World)|page=528|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vuM-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA528&lpg=PA528|accessdate=20 July 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Wireless To The New York|title=TWO OF THE HARRIMANS SEEK PARIS DIVORCES; Mrs. Lillie Harriman Havemeyer and Mrs. Ethel Harriman Russell File Petitions.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1925/06/25/archives/two-of-the-harrimans-seek-paris-divorces-mrs-lillie-harriman.html|accessdate=20 July 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=25 June 1925}} Havemeyer died [[intestate]] at his home, 244 Madison Avenue in [[New York City]], on April 26, 1897. His funeral service was held at [[St. Patrick's Cathedral (Manhattan)|St. Patrick's Cathedral]] in New York and he was buried at [[Green-Wood Cemetery]].{{cite news|title=FUNERAL OF MR. HAVEMEYER; Impressive Services in St. Patrick's Cathedral in the Presence of a Great Throng. THE ARCHBISHOP OFFICIATED Father Sylvester Malone Celebrated the Solemn Requiem Mass for His Friend -- Interment Was in Greenwood Cemetery -- Refineries Closed in Williamsburg.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/04/30/archives/funeral-of-mr-havemeyer-impressive-services-in-st-patricks.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 April 1897}}{{cite news|title=IN MEMORY OF MR. HAVEMEYER.; Consecration of Vestments Presented to the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/10/11/archives/in-memory-of-mr-havemeyer-consecration-of-vestments-presented-to.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 October 1897}} He left an estate valued at $4 million.{{cite news|title=ESTATE OF T.A. HAVEMEYER; Mr. Parsons Thinks It Will Not Be "Less Than Might Have Been Expected." NO WILL HAS BEEN FOUND The Heirs Will Proceed on the Idea that Mr. Havemeyer Died Intestate --A Plan Had Been Drawn Up but Never Executed.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1897/05/12/archives/estate-of-ta-havemeyer-mr-parsons-thinks-it-will-not-be-less-than.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 May 1897}} ==See also== *[[Havemeyer]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === * {{cite book |last1=Frelinghuysen |first1=Alice Cooney |last2=Tinterow |first2= Gary |last3=Stein |first3=Susan Alyson |last4=Wold |first4=Gretchen |last5=Meech |first5=Julia |title=Splendid Legacy: The Havemeyer Collection |year=1993 |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art |location=New York |isbn=978-0-300-08617-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5VUheKAVZ3QC |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Havemeyer |first=Harry W. |title=Merchants of Williamsburgh |year=1989 |publisher=privately printed |location=New York}} * {{cite book |last=Havemeyer II |first=Henry O. |title=Biographical Record of the Havemeyer Family |year=1944 |publisher=privately printed |location=New York |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Havemeyer |first=Louisine W. |title=Sixteen to Sixty: Memoirs of a Collector |origyear=1961 |year=1993 |publisher=Ursus Press |location=New York |isbn=1-883145-00-7}} == External links == * {{findagrave|58053211}} * [http://www.library.hbs.edu/hc/wes/indexes/alpha/content/1001956064.html Theodore Havemeyer Collection at Harvard Business School] {{DEFAULTSORT:Havemeyer, Theodore}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Businesspeople in the sugar industry]] [[Category:Golf administrators]] [[Category:1839 births]] [[Category:1897 deaths]] [[Category:Havemeyer family|Theodore]] [[Category:Burials at Green-Wood Cemetery]] [[Category:American sugar industry]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]]

{{For|the Tibetan village|Tomra, Tibet}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{infobox company | name = Tomra Systems ASA | logo = Tomra.svg | logo_size = 210px | type = [[Allmennaksjeselskap]] | traded_as = {{ose|TOM}} | foundation = 1972 <ref name="About_Tomra">{{cite news|title=History : TOMRA|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/about-us/history/|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=www.tomra.com|publisher=TOMRA SYSTEMS ASA}}</ref> | location = [[Asker]], [[Norway]] | key_people = Hans Stefan Ranstrand <small>(President and [[chief executive officer|CEO]])</small>, Jan Svensson <small>([[Chairman]])</small> | area_served = | industry = [[Recycling]] | products = [[Reverse vending machine]]s, , [[compactor]]s, and [[sensor-based sorting]] equipment | revenue = {{increase}}NOK 7.432 billion <small>(2017)</small><ref name="AR2016">{{cite web|url=http://mb.cision.com/Public/4659/2231503/8d1c1a2aa48cbc3c.pdf |title=TOMRA Annual Report 2016|publisher=Tomra Systems ASA |date= |accessdate=2017-04-18}}</ref><ref name="AR2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/-/media/documents/group-downloads/tomra_annualreport_2017_lores_spreads.ashx?la=en&hash=8ABE61665A919CCD6E1AA361837EF9EF320FA53E |title=TOMRA Annual Report 2017|publisher=Tomra Systems ASA |date= |accessdate=2018-04-29}}</ref> | assets = {{increase}}NOK 8.437 billion <small>(end 2017)</small><ref name="AR2016" /><ref name="AR2017" /> | equity = {{increase}}NOK 4.594 billion <small>(end 2017)</small><ref name="AR2016" /><ref name="AR2017" /> | num_employees = {{increase}} 3,420 <small>(end 2017)</small><ref name="AR2016" /><ref name="AR2017" /> | parent = | subsid = TOMRA CONNECT | homepage = {{URL|tomra.com}} }}
'''Tomra Systems ASA''' is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[multinational corporation]] active in the field of instrumentation for recycling solutions. The company is the largest<ref>{{cite web|title=Sumitomo Corporation Establishes Joint Company with World's Largest Reverse Vending Machine (RVM) Maker, Tomra｜ Sumitomo Corporation|url=http://www.sumitomocorp.co.jp/english/news/detail/id=26390|website=Sumitomo Corporation|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref> [[Reverse vending machine|Reverse Vending Machine (RVM)]] producer globally and leading sensor-based machines for sorting and recycling.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fallan|first1= Kjetil|title=Scandinavian design : alternative histories|date=2012|publisher=Berg|location=London|isbn=9781847889119|pages=Chp. 5|edition=English}}</ref> In addition to [[Reverse vending machine|RVMs]], TOMRA manufactures [[compactor]]s, [[material recovery]], and sorting machinery.<ref name="tomra.com">[http://www.tomra.com/default.asp?V_ITEM_ID=422 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111012160825/http://www.tomra.com/default.asp?V_ITEM_ID=422 |date=12 October 2011 }}</ref> With over 70,000 [[Reverse vending machine|RVMs]] installed worldwide, TOMRA is the leading provider in the industry.<ref name="Oslo_Bors">{{cite news|title=TOMRA: Presentation materials DNB Markets SME Conference|url=http://www.newsweb.no/newsweb/search.do?messageId=397493&siteLanguage=en|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=www.newsweb.no|publisher=Oslo Stock Exchange}}</ref>
TOMRA is listed on the [[Oslo Stock Exchange]] (OSEBX) under the [[ticker symbol]] TOM.<ref>{{cite web|title=TOM:Oslo Stock Quote - Tomra Systems ASA|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/TOM:NO|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref> The parent company, Tomra Systems ASA, is headquartered in [[Asker, Norway]], with central departments located in [[Mülheim-Kärlich]], [[Germany]] and [[Shelton, Connecticut]].<ref name="About_Tomra"/>
==History==
=== 1970's === TOMRA was founded by the two brothers [[Tore Planke|Tore]] and [[Petter Planke]] in 1972. It started out with the design, manufacturing and sale of [[reverse vending machine]]s (RVMs) for automated collection of used [[beverage containers]].<ref name="About_Tomra"/> Through 70s a breakthrough for Tomra was in 1974 where the Swedish entity [[Systembolaget]] ordered 100 RVMs.<ref name="Green_Machine">{{cite book|last1=Jørgensen|first1=Finn Arne|title=Making a green machine : the infrastructure of beverage container recycling|date=2011|publisher=Rutgers University Press|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=978-0813550541}}</ref>
=== 1980s-2000s === TOMRA was listed in [[Oslo Børs]] on 18 January 1985<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oslobors.no/ob_eng/markedsaktivitet/#/details/TOM.OSE/data|title=Tomra Systems: Details|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Oslo Børs]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> and tried to secure a position in the American market to no avail.<ref name="Green_Machine"/> It was then successfully attempted to enter the market in 1990s. By 1999, sales in the US accounted for more than half of total revenues. In 2006, TOMRA delivered more than 8000 new reverse vending systems to Germany.<ref name="Green_Machine"/>
TOMRA's sensor-based sorting technology business was first established in 2004 with the acquisition of ''TiTech Visionsort AS'', a provider of optical recognition and sorting technology<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/news-and-media/news/2004/tomra-acquires-leading-recycling-company/|title=TOMRA acquires leading recycling company|last=|first=|date=2004-07-12|website=Tomra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> (which was renamed to ''Tomra Sorting Solutions'' in 2012<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://waste-management-world.com/a/titech-rebrands-as-tomra-sorting-solutions|title=Titech Rebrands as Tomra Sorting Solutions|last=|first=|date=2012-02-17|website=Waste Management World|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>), from ''Ferd AS'' for 219 million NOK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/news-and-media/news/2004/formal-closing-of-titech-acquisition-completed/|title=Formal closing of TiTech acquisition completed|last=|first=|date=2004-08-25|website=Tomra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
With the acquisition of ''Orwak'' in 2005,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.recyclingtoday.com/article/tomra-systems-asa-acquires-orwak-group-ab/|title=Tomra Systems ASA Acquires Orwak Group AB; reverse vending manufacturers secures shares in baling operation|last=|first=|date=2005-03-04|website=Recycling Today|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> TOMRA established itself as a producer of compaction and baling solutions with an installed base of more than 67,000 [[baler]]s.<ref>[http://www.tomra.com/default.asp?V_ITEM_ID=1273] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921171658/http://www.tomra.com/default.asp?V_ITEM_ID=1273 |date=21 September 2012 }}</ref> In December 2014, TOMRA sold the ''Orwak'' operations in Norway, Sweden, Poland and Japan under the name ''TOMRA Compaction'' to ''San Sac Nordic AB'' of Sweden.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/news-and-media/news/2014/tomra-compaction-acquired-by-san-sac/|title=TOMRA Compaction acquired by San Sac|last=|first=|date=2014-12-15|website=Tomra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
As of August 31, 2005, ''TOMRA Latasa Reciclagem S.A.'', offering aluminium can collection and recycling assets services in Brazil, Chile, and Argentina, was acquired by [[Aleris International, Inc.]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=23723280|title=Company Overview of Tomra Latasa Reciclagem S.A.|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
On 1 July 2006, TOMRA’s subsidiary ''Titech Visionsort AS'' acquired 100 percent of the shares of Germany-based ''CommoDaS GmbH'', a provider of recognition and sorting technology for metals, plastics, glass, minerals and gems, for approximately 100 million NOK.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/news-and-media/news/2006/acquisition-of-commodas-gmbh/|title=Acquisition of CommoDas GmbH|last=|first=|date=2006-06-07|website=Tomra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
On 1 Juli 2008 TOMRA announced it bought Australian peer ''Ultrasort Group'', a provider of advanced recognition and sorting technology to the mining industry, for 160 million NOK ($31.48 million).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/ultrasort-tomra-idINOSL00136820080701|title=Tomra buys Australian Ultrasort for $31 mln|last=|first=|date=2008-07-01|website=[[Reuters]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
=== 2010-2016 === Via several acquisitions, TOMRA had grown into a global company since the 2000s and secured 75% global market share in [[Reverse vending machine|RVMs]] and 60% Material Recovery from Collection Solutions and 40%-65% in Sorting Solutions.<ref name="Oslo_Bors"/>
On 12 December 2010, TOMRA's subsidiary ''TiTech'' acquired [[Dublin]]-based food technology company ''Odenberg'', a designer of equipment used for producing 65 per cent of all [[French fries]] worldwide, for up to 57.5 million Euro from ''ACT Venture Capital'' in Dublin and members of the Van den Bergh family in Belgium;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/irish-food-tech-firm-odenberg-sold-for-up-to-57-5m-1.687350|title=Irish food tech firm Odenberg sold for up to €57.5m|last=Hancock|first=Ciaran|date=2010-12-15|website=[[The Irish Times]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> Odenberg's chilling/freezing unit was later considered a non-core business and sold in 2013 as to a newly formed company, ''Power Food Technology Ltd.'', of Ireland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.foodengineeringmag.com/articles/90662-new-types-of-foreign-material-a?page=2|title=Mergers and Acquisitions in Inspection Systems|last=Knights|first=Mikell|date=2013-05-13|website=Food Engineering|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
On 31 December 2011, TOMRA sold the assets of ''Tomra Pacific, Inc.'', a recycler of used beverage containers in California, to ''rePlanet, LLC'' for approximately $25 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://inpublic.globenewswire.com/2012/01/02/TOMRA+divests+its+California+operation+HUG1574496.html|title=TOMRA divests its California operation|last=|first=|date=2012-01-02|website=[[GlobeNewswire]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
In June 2012, TOMRA purchased 100% of Belgium-based food [[Optical sorting|sorting]] specialist ''Best Kwadraat'' for 138 million Euro.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bakeryandsnacks.com/Processing-Packaging/Best-acquired-by-TOMRA-Group-for-138m|title=Best acquired by TOMRA Group for €138m|last=Harrington|first=Rory|date=2012-06-04|website=Bakery and Snacks|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
In October 2016 TOMRA signed an agreement to acquire ''Compac Holding Ltd.,'' a New Zealand-based provider of packing house automation systems that sort fresh produce based on weight, size, shape, color, surface blemishes, and internal quality,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU1610/S00354/tomra-acquires-nz-sorting-machine-manufacturer-compac.htm|title=TOMRA acquires NZ Sorting Machine Manufacturer Compac|last=|first=|date=2016-10-12|website=Scoop Business|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> for $70 million plus up to $230 million in earn-outs available to Compac founders;<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/article/correct-230m-earn-outs-available-compac-vendors-assuming-turnaround-b-200119|title=Up to $230 million in earn-outs available to Compac founders|last=Smellie|first=Pattrick|date=2017-03-01|website=National Business Review|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> the transaction was completed in March 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/solutions-and-products/sorting-solutions/food/newsletter-food-for-thought/2017/a-closer-look-compac/|title=TOMRA completes COMPAC acquisition|last=|first=|date=2017-03-08|website=Tomra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>
== Competition law compliance == In 2001, the EU Commission performed an investigation of Tomra’s competition law compliance. Based on this investigation, the Commission concluded in March 2006 that TOMRA in their opinion had foreclosed competition in the period 1998 to 2002 in the market for reverse vending machines in Austria, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway and Sweden by implementing an exclusionary strategy. TOMRA appealed the decision to the European General Court in 2006.
In September 2010, the Court issued their judgment where they dismissed Tomra’s appeal both on the substance and on the amount of the fine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:62006TJ0155&from=EN|title=JUDGMENT OF THE GENERAL COURT (Fifth Chamber): Case T-155/06 Tomra Systems ASA and Others vs European Commission|last=|first=|date=2010-09-09|website=eur-lex.europa.eu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> TOMRA consequently accrued 28.2 million Euro (NOK 226.1 million) for the fine and accumulated interest in the third quarter financial statement for 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomra.com/en/news-and-media/news/2010/third-quarter-2010-results/|title=Third quarter 2010 results|last=|first=|date=2010-10-19|website=Tomra|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref> TOMRA appealed this decision again but finally lost the case in April 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://united-kingdom.taylorwessing.com/en/news-insights/details/when-will-discounts-and-rebates-in-supply-agreements-be-anti-competitive-2012-05-09.html|title=When will discounts and rebates in supply agreements be anti-competitive?|last=|first=|date=2012-05-09|website=[[Taylor Wessing]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-10}}</ref>[[File:Tomra T-820 BC Blue.jpg|thumb|right|The images shows a TOMRA T-820 BC (Bottle and Crate) machine.]]

revision.text:
'''"Tone at the top"''' is a term that originated in the field of [[accounting]] and is used to describe an organization's general ethical climate, as established by its board of directors, audit committee, and senior management. Having good tone at the top is believed by business ethics experts to help prevent fraud and other unethical practices.<ref>{{cite web|title=TONE AT THE TOP Definition|url=http://www.ventureline.com/accounting-glossary/T/tone-at-the-top-definition/|publisher=VentureLine}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wood|first1=David A.|title=An Examination of How Entry-Level Staff Auditors Respond to Tone at the Top vis-à-vis Tone at the Bottom|journal=Behavioral Research in Accounting|date=Spring 2015|volume=27|issue=1|url=http://www.aaajournals.org/doi/abs/10.2308/bria-50918}}</ref>
==Origins== The concept of tone at the top originated in [[Big Four (audit firms)|audit firms]], where it referred fairly narrowly to the attitude of an organization's senior leadership towards [[Internal control|internal financial controls]]. It was popularized following a series of major [[corporate accounting scandals]] such as those affecting [[Enron]], [[Tyco International]], [[Adelphia Communications Corporation|Adelphia]], [[Peregrine Systems]] and [[WorldCom]], when the concept was strongly emphasized in the [[Sarbanes–Oxley Act|Sarbanes–Oxley Act of 2002]] as important in the prevention and detection of [[fraud]] and other unethical financial practices. Today the term is applied very broadly, including in the fields of general management, [[information security]], law and [[software development]], and is often used to describe the general corporate culture established by an organization's leadership.<ref>{{cite book|last=Krause|first=edited by Harold F. Tipton, Micki|title=Information security management handbook, v. 3|year=2000|publisher=Auerbach|location=Boca Raton, Fl|isbn=1420090925|pages=133–134|edition=6th}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Terry|title=Your Time or Your Money: Groundswell supports less billable hours, alternate tracks to the top|newspaper=The ABA Journal {{!}} The lawyer's magazine|date=February 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Perry|first=William E.|title=Effective methods for software testing|year=2006|publisher=Wiley Publishing|location=Indianapolis, Ind.|isbn=0764598376|pages=51 and 60|edition=3rd ed. --}}</ref>
==Overview== The tone at the top is often considered to permeate an entire organization, and good tone at the top is considered a prerequisite for solid [[corporate governance]]. It has been said that [[Board of directors|boards of directors]] have a dual role: creating codes of conduct, and living by them.<ref>{{cite book|last=O'Regan|first=David|title=Auditor's Dictionary: Terms, Concepts, Processes, and Regulations.|year=2004|publisher=John Wiley and Sons Ltd|location=New York|isbn=0471531189|pages=257|edition=[Online-Ausg.]}}</ref>
Good organizational tone is set through policies, codes of ethics, a commitment to hiring competent employees, and the development of [[reward structures]] that promote good internal controls and effective governance. In an analysis of ethical leadership, [[KPMG]] described ethical leaders as those who are receptive to employees' ethical concerns, value ethics and integrity over short-term business goals, and respond appropriately if they become aware of misconduct.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dunn|first=Leonard J. Brooks, Paul|title=Business & professional ethics for directors, executives, & accountants|year=2010|publisher=South Western Cengage Learning|location=Mason, OH|isbn=0324594550|pages=261|edition=5th}}</ref>
Auditors typically interview an organization's leaders as part of the [[audit fieldwork]] in order to assess tone at the top, because poor tone is associated with malfeasance. Questions commonly asked include "how is the board compensated," "how active is the [[audit committee]]," "what is the nature of the organization's [[corporate culture]]," "what pressures are there to make [[sales targets|sales and earnings goals]]," "how is wrong-doing dealt with," "do employees understand their individual responsibilities for controls," "do monitoring controls signal failures in a timely fashion so corrective action can be taken," and "is there evidence that the employee [[Ethical code|code of ethics]] is complied with."<ref>{{cite book|last=Johnstone|first=Larry E. Rittenberg, Bradley J. Schwieger, Karla M.|title=Auditing: a business risk approach|year=2008|publisher=Thomson/South-Western|location=Mason, OH|isbn=0324375581|pages=353–354|edition=6th}}</ref>
Important fraud factors include pressure to reach goals, incentives and meeting expectations.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Management can prevent fraud in the Workplace|url=http://www.acfe.com/uploadedFiles/ACFE_Website/Content/documents/tone-at-the-top-research.pdf|publisher=Association of Certified Fraud Examiners|accessdate=26 September 2012}}</ref>
==Failures== Experts say that weaknesses in the "tone at the top" have been associated with most modern financial frauds. Poor tone at the top may include a disdain for [[internal control]]s, an overemphasis on [[Profit (accounting)|profits]] at the expense of [[Business ethics|ethics]], a belief that [[Legal governance, risk management, and compliance#Legal compliance|compliance with the law]] is sufficient for defensible ethical conduct, the canvassing and accommodating of some [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] but not others, blaming higher-ups or colleagues for unethical practices, having one's judgement clouded due to [[Conflict of interest|conflicts of interest]], and a misunderstanding of and lack of adherence to public expectations of what constitutes ethical behaviour for executives.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gramling|first=Larry E. Rittenberg, Karla M. Johnstone, Audrey A.|title=Auditing: a business risk approach|year=2010|publisher=South-Western Cengage Learning|location=Mason, OH|isbn=0324658044|pages=195 and 233|edition=7th}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dunn|first=Leonard J. Brooks, Paul|title=Business & professional ethics for directors, executives, & accountants|year=2010|publisher=South Western Cengage Learning|location=Mason, OH|isbn=0324594550|pages=202–205|edition=5th}}</ref> [[Options backdating|Backdating]] [[Employee stock option|stock options]] and pegging the granting of options to significant good or bad corporate announcements (known as [[Options backdating#Terminology|spring-loading and bullet-dodging]]) are [[Executive compensation|compensation practices]] that can be indicative of poor tone at the top.<ref>{{cite book|last=Braiotta|first=Louis, Jr.|title=The audit committee handbook|year=2010|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, N.J.|isbn=0470560487|edition=5th}}</ref>
===Examples of failed tone at the top===
====The Enron scandal==== The [[Enron scandal]], revealed in October 2001, eventually led to the bankruptcy of the [[Enron Corporation]], an American energy company based in [[Houston Texas|Houston, Texas]], and the de facto dissolution of [[Arthur Andersen]], its audit firm. Enron is considered to be the largest [[bankruptcy]] reorganization in U.S. history, as well as the biggest audit failure.<ref name="DarkSide61">{{cite journal|last=Bratton|first=William W.|title=Does Corporate Law Protect the Interests of Shareholders and Other Stakeholders?: Enron and the Dark Side of Shareholder Value|journal=[[Tulane Law Review]]|volume=|issue=1275|page=61|publisher=[[Tulane University Law School]]|location=New Orleans|date=May 2002|ssrn=301475|format=PDF|doi=|accessdate=}}</ref> Executives at Enron used [[Creative accounting|accounting loopholes]], [[special purpose entities]], and misleading [[financial reporting]] to hide billions in debt from failed deals and projects. [[Chief Financial Officer]] [[Andrew Fastow]] and other executives not only misled Enron's board of directors and audit committee on high-risk [[Standard accounting practice|accounting practices]], but also pressured Andersen to ignore the issues. The Enron story demonstrated many common features of failed tone at the top, including inappropriate hostility to critics and a misunderstanding of public expectations. In a conference call on April 17, 2001, after [[Wall Street]] [[Business analyst|analyst]] [[Richard Grubman]] complained that Enron wasn't releasing a [[balance sheet]] along with its [[financial statements]], then-CEO [[Jeffrey Skilling]] responded "Well, thank you very much, we appreciate that ... asshole," a phrase that was met with dismay and astonishment by the media and public, but which became an inside joke among many Enron employees.<ref name="million">{{cite news|last=Pasha|first=Shaheen|url=http://money.cnn.com/2006/04/10/news/newsmakers/enron_trial/index.htm|publisher=[[CNNMoney.com]]|title=Skilling comes out swinging|date=2006-04-10|accessdate=2010-10-17|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tZ2GOn06|archivedate=2010-10-17}}</ref><ref name="WellThankYou">{{cite news|last=Tolson|first=Mike|author2=Katherine Feser |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/jenny/2404018.html|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|title=Jeff Skilling's spectacular career|date=2004-06-20|accessdate=2010-10-17|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tZ2J4D0c|archivedate=2010-10-17}}</ref><ref name="EmpAskWhy">{{cite news|last=Niles|first=Sam|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/07/10/ceo-anger-management-ceonetwork-leadership-outbursts_slide_2.html|work=[[Forbes]]|title=In Pictures: 10 All-Time Great CEO Outbursts: Jeffrey Skilling|date=2009-07-10|accessdate=2010-10-17|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tZ2MXiZi|archivedate=2010-10-17}}</ref>
====Arthur Andersen obstruction of justice==== [[Arthur Andersen]] was criticized for being the only [[Big Four (audit firms)|Big 5]] audit firm to allow the partner in charge of an audit to override a ruling made by the quality control partner, and was found guilty in 2002 of obstruction of justice for shredding documents related to its audit of Enron, resulting in the Enron scandal. The Arthur Andersen story is now used in business ethics textbooks as an example of a failure of tone at the top, for emphasizing profitability over high ethical standards.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dunn|first=Leonard J. Brooks, Paul|title=Business & professional ethics for directors, executives, & accountants|year=2010|publisher=South Western Cengage Learning|location=Mason, OH|isbn=0324594550|pages=117–123|edition=5th}}</ref> ''See also [[Arthur Andersen LLP v. United States]] and the [[Enron scandal]].''
====Xerox fined by SEC==== In 2002, [[Xerox]] was fined $10 million by the U.S. [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) for allegedly deceiving the public between 1997 and 2000 by employing several "accounting maneuvers," with six Xerox senior executives paying another $22 million in 2003. The SEC charged that former CEO [[Paul Allaire]] and his second-in-command [[G. Richard Thoman]], who were among the six fined, "set a tone at the top of the company which equated business success with meeting short-term earnings targets."<ref>{{cite book|last=Markham|first=Jerry W.|title=A financial history of modern U.S. corporate scandals: from Enron to reform|year=2005|publisher=Sharpe|location=Armonk, N.Y. [u.a.]|isbn=0765615835|pages=224|edition=[Online-Ausg.]}}</ref>
====Scandals at Fannie Mae==== Business experts say that although the U.S. Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA), colloquially known as [[Fannie Mae]], gave the appearance of setting the appropriate tone at the top, its actual conduct fell short. In 2004, Fannie Mae was investigated by the U.S. [[Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight]] (OFHEO), which alleged widespread accounting errors. In 2008 Fannie Mae was embroiled in several conflict of interest scandals, and in 2011 six of its executives, including 2005-2008 Fannie Mae CEO [[Daniel Mudd]], were charged by the U.S. [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] with [[securities fraud]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Cristie|first=James R. (editor)|title=Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac: scandal in US housing|year=2007|publisher=Novinka Books|location=New York, NY|isbn=1600213561|pages=44–46}}</ref> In May 2006, OFHEO released a "Report of the Special Examination of Fannie Mae" which argued that at Fannie Mae "earnings mattered, but not how they were achieved," and which blamed "the actions and inactions of the Board of Directors [which] inappropriately reinforced rather than checked the tone and culture set by [1999-2004 Fannie Mae CEO Franklin] Raines and other senior managers."<ref>{{cite book|last=Gup|first=ed. by Benton E.|title=Corporate governance in banking: a global perspective|year=2007|publisher=Elgar|location=Cheltenham [u.a.]|isbn=1845429400|pages=32–33}}</ref> Former OFHEA head [[Armando Falcon]] attributed Fannie Mae's problems to "the arrogance and huge egos of senior management," saying "it was always just groupthink and if you ever raised a dissenting voice, your career would be over. Ego and arrogance was visible everywhere, in everything the company did: how it treated counterparties in the marketplace it dealt in, how it was able to throw its weight around politically, the way it spent money to curry political loyalty, the arrogance that permeated everything that the company did, including ultimately the accounting misconduct, and the lack of any kind of corporate ethics."<ref>{{cite book|last=Gillespie|first=John|title=Money for nothing: how the failure of corporate boards is ruining American business and costing us trillions|year=2010|publisher=Free Press|location=New York|isbn=1416559930|pages=124–125|edition=1st Free Press hardcover|author2=Zweig, David }}</ref> ''See also the [[Fannie Mae#Accounting controversy|2004 Fannie Mae accounting controversy]], the [[Countrywide financial political loan scandal|Countrywide Financial political loan scandal]] and [[Angelo Mozilo#.22Friends of Angelo .28FOA.29.22 VIP program|Friends of Angelo VIP program]], and the [[Fannie Mae#2011 SEC charges|2011 Fannie Mae SEC charges]].''
====Global financial crisis==== The [[2007–2012 global financial crisis]], considered by many [[economist]]s to be the worst [[financial crisis]] since the [[Great Depression]] of the 1930s,<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS193520+27-Feb-2009+BW20090227 Two top economists agree 2009 worst financial crisis since great depression; risks increase if right steps are not taken.] (February 29, 2009). ''[[Reuters]]''. Retrieved 2009-09-30, from [[Business Wire|Business Wire News]] database.</ref> was investigated by the U.S. [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]], which concluded that "the crisis was avoidable and was caused by: Widespread failures in financial regulation, including the Federal Reserve’s failure to stem the tide of toxic mortgages; Dramatic breakdowns in corporate governance including too many financial firms acting recklessly and taking on too much risk; An explosive mix of excessive borrowing and risk by households and Wall Street that put the financial system on a collision course with crisis; Key policy makers ill prepared for the crisis, lacking a full understanding of the financial system they oversaw; and systemic breaches in accountability and ethics at all levels,"<ref>[http://www.fcic.gov/files/news_pdfs/2011-0127-fcic-releases-report.pdf Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission – Press Release – January 27, 2011] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130170725/http://www.fcic.gov/files/news_pdfs/2011-0127-fcic-releases-report.pdf |date=January 30, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://c0182732.cdn1.cloudfiles.rackspacecloud.com/fcic_final_report_conclusions.pdf FCIC Report-Conclusions Excerpt-January 2011]</ref> and laid the blame for the crisis with government and regulatory leaders and CEOs of the failed companies, saying "tone at the top does matter and, in this instance, we were let down. No one said 'no'."<ref>{{cite book|last=Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission|title=The financial crisis inquiry report: final report of the National Commission on the Causes of the Financial and Economic Crisis in the United States|publisher=Public Affairs|location=New York, N.Y.|isbn=1610390415|pages=xxiii|edition=1st ed., Authorized edition.}}</ref>
====[[Tyco International#Corporate scandal of 2002|Tyco Scandal]]==== {{Main|Tyco International#Corporate scandal of 2002}}
Former [[chairman]] and [[chief executive]] [[Dennis Kozlowski]] and former [[chief financial officer]] Mark H. Swartz were accused of the theft of more than $150 million from the company. During their trial in March 2004, they contended the board of directors authorized it as compensation.
During jury deliberations, juror Ruth Jordan, while passing through the courtroom, appeared to make an [[A-ok|"okay" sign]] with her fingers to the defense table. She later denied she had intended that gesture, but the incident received much publicity (including a caricature in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''), and the juror received threats after her name became public. Judge Michael Obus declared a [[mistrial (law)|mistrial]] on April 2, 2004.
On June 17, 2005, after a retrial, Kozlowski and Swartz were convicted on all but one of the more than 30 counts against them. The verdicts carry potential jail terms of up to 25 years in state prison. Kozlowski himself was sentenced to no less than eight years and four months and no more than 25 years in prison. Swartz received the same sentence. Then in May 2007, [[New Hampshire]] Federal District Court Judge [[Paul Barbadoro]] approved a class action settlement whereby Tyco agreed to pay $2.92 billion (in conjunction with $225 million by [[Pricewaterhouse Coopers]], their auditors) to a class of defrauded shareholders represented by [[Grant & Eisenhofer P.A.]], Schiffrin, Barroway, Topaz & Kessler, and Milberg Weiss & Bershad.
====[[MCI Inc.|MCI Inc/WorldCom]]==== {{Main|MCI_Inc.#Accounting_scandals}}
CEO Bernard Ebbers was accused of accounting fraud.<ref name=sec>{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/723527/000093176303001862/dex991.htm|title=Report of Investigation by The Special Investigative Committee of the Board of Directors of Worldcom, Inc.|publisher=SEC| accessdate=2008-01-04 }}</ref> Ebbers had become very wealthy from the rising price of his holdings in WorldCom common stock.<ref name="sec"/> However, in the year 2000, the telecommunications industry entered a downturn <!-- page 33 of Worldcom report -->and WorldCom’s aggressive growth strategy suffered a serious setback when it was forced by the US Justice Department to abandon its proposed merger with Sprint in mid 2000.<ref name="sec"/> By that time, WorldCom’s stock price was declining and Ebbers came under increasing pressure from banks to cover [[margin call]]s on his WorldCom stock that was used to finance his other businesses (timber and yachting, among others).<ref name=sec /> During 2001, Ebbers persuaded WorldCom’s board of directors to provide him corporate loans and guarantees in excess of $400 million to cover his margin calls.<ref name=sec /> The board hoped that the loans would avert the need for Ebbers to sell substantial amounts of his WorldCom stock, as his doing so would put further downward pressure on the stock's price. However, this strategy ultimately failed and Ebbers was ousted as CEO in April 2002 and replaced by [[John W. Sidgmore|John Sidgmore]], former [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[UUNET]] Technologies, Inc.
Beginning modestly in mid-year 1999 and continuing at an accelerated pace through May 2002, the company (under the direction of Ebbers, [[Scott Sullivan (executive)|Scott Sullivan]] (CFO), David Myers ([[Comptroller]]) and Buford "Buddy" Yates (Director of General Accounting)) used fraudulent accounting methods to mask its declining earnings by painting a false picture of financial growth and profitability to prop up the price of WorldCom’s stock.<ref name=sec />
The fraud was accomplished primarily in two ways:
#Booking ‘line costs’ (interconnection expenses with other telecommunication companies) as [[capital expenditure|capital]] on the balance sheet instead of [[expense]]s. #Inflating revenues with bogus accounting entries from "corporate unallocated revenue accounts".
In 2002, a small team of internal auditors at WorldCom worked together, often at night and in secret, to investigate and unearth $3.8 billion in fraud.<ref name=WallStreetJournal>{{cite news |first=Susan |last=Pulliam |author2=Deborah Soloman |title=How Three Unlikely Sleuths Exposed Fraud at WorldCom: Firm's Own Employees Sniffed Out Cryptic Clues and Followed Hunches |url=http://www.happinessonline.org/MoralCode/LiveWithTruth/p23.htm |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=2008-11-08}}</ref><ref name=Time2002b>{{cite news |first=Amanda |last=Ripley |authorlink=Amanda Ripley |title=The Night Detective |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1003990,00.html |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=2008-11-08 | date=December 30, 2002}}</ref><ref name=ExtraCircPatsyLee>{{cite book |last=Cooper|first=Cynthia |authorlink= |editor= |others= |title=Extraordinary Circumstances: The Journey of a Corporate Whistleblower |url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0470124296/ref=sib_dp_pt# |accessdate=2008-11-08|series= |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|John Wiley & Sons, Inc.]] |location=[[Hoboken, New Jersey]] |isbn=9780470124291 }}</ref> Shortly thereafter, the company’s audit committee and board of directors were notified of the fraud and acted swiftly: Sullivan was fired, Myers resigned, [[Arthur Andersen]] withdrew its audit opinion for 2001, and the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) launched an investigation into these matters on June 26, 2002 (see [[accounting scandals]]). By the end of 2003, it was estimated that the company's total assets had been inflated by around $11 billion.<ref name=sec />
====[[ImClone Systems]] trading case==== {{Main|ImClone stock trading case}}
ImClone's stock price dropped sharply at the end of 2001 when its drug [[Cetuximab|Erbitux]], an experimental [[monoclonal antibody]], failed to get the expected [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) approval. It was later revealed by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] that numerous executives sold their stock before the announcement of the decision after the close of trading on December 28.
Its founder, [[Samuel D. Waksal]], was arrested in 2002 on [[insider trading]] charges for informing friends and family to sell their stock, and attempting to sell his own. His daughter, Aliza Waksal, sold $2.5 million in shares on December 27. His father, Jack Waksal, sold $8.1 million in shares over the 27th and 28th. Company executives had done the same. [[John B. Landes]], the general counsel, sold $2.5 million in shares on December 6. [[Ronald A. Martell]], the vice president for marketing and sales, sold $2.1 million in shares on December 11. Four other executives sold shares in the following weeks as well. Later, Samuel Waksal pleaded guilty to various charges, including [[securities fraud]], and on June 10, 2003, was sentenced to seven years and three months in prison.

'''Vladimir Petrovich Alganov''' ({{lang-ru|Владимир Петрович Алганов}}; born 22 October 1952 in [[Leningrad]]) is a Russian spy. He was Soviet [[KGB]] officer in Warsaw, Poland in the 1980s and Russian [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|SVR]] officer in the same city in the 1990s.
In 1996, Poland's Prime Minister [[Józef Oleksy]] resigned because of his links to Alganov.<ref>{{cite news | title = Polish PM forced to resign over links with KGB man | publisher = The Independent | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/polish-pm-forced-to-resign-over-links-with-kgb-man-1325658.html | date=25 January 1996 | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | location=London}}</ref>
Alganov was deported from Poland in 1997.<ref name="stealthroute"/>
In 2005 Lithuanian authorities said that Alganov had been issued a long-term Lithuanian visa in 2002 and Alganov had met managers of the [[Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Chronicle of Russian Espionage in the Baltic Countries | publisher = Axis Globe | url = http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=49 | date = 2005-04-20 | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070914005458/http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=49 | archive-date = 2007-09-14 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Baltic News (2005/01) | publisher = Baltics Worldwide | url = http://www.balticsworldwide.com/baltic-news-200501/ | date=January 2005 | accessdate = 2009-10-17}}</ref>
In 2003, Alganov secretly met [[Jan Kulczyk]] in a restaurant in Vienna, Austria. The conversation was recorded by Polish intelligence officers. According to [[Antoni Macierewicz]], a member of the investigative board: * Alganov offered Kulczyk $5 million to influence Poland's then-President [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]].<ref name="stealthroute"/> * Alganov said that six months earlier, Russians had paid $1m to the Minister of Finance [[Wiesław Kaczmarek]] for the Russian company [[Lukoil]] to win the privatization tender for a refinery in Gdansk.<ref name="stealthroute">{{cite news | title = From Poland to Hungary, Gazprom takes stealth route to domination | publisher = The Independent | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/from-poland-to-hungary-gazprom-takes-stealth-route-to-domination-522003.html | date=8 January 2006 | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | location=London | first=Neil | last=Barnett}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Oil scandal rocks Polish leadership - Some fear Moscow gaining influence | publisher = The Boston Globe | url = http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2004/12/05/oil_scandal_rocks_polish_leadership/ | date=2004-12-05 | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | first1=Jeffrey | last1=Fleishman}}</ref><ref>[http://www.maxwell.syr.edu/moynihan/programs/ces/pcconfpdfs/Kennedy.pdf The cultural politics of military alliances and energy security] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070317092815/http://www.maxwell.syr.edu/moynihan/programs/ces/pcconfpdfs/Kennedy.pdf |date=2007-03-17 }}. Michael D. Kennedy. September 23, 2005.</ref>
Also present at the meeting was [[Aleksander Żagiel]], Alganov's Vienna-based business partner.<ref>[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-14348382_ITM Polish oil case businessman fails to show before commission, "ill" in London]. Asia Africa Intelligence Wire. November 09, 2004.</ref>

[[HBO Pictures]] | distributor = HBO | budget = | network = [[HBO]] | first_aired = {{start date|1994|5|21}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''White Mile''''' is a 1994 American [[television film|made-for-television]] [[thriller film|thriller-drama film]] directed by [[Robert Butler (director)|Robert Butler]] and starring [[Alan Alda]], [[Peter Gallagher]] and [[Robert Loggia]]. It originally premiered on [[HBO]] on May 21, 1994. == Plot summary == Dan Cutler, the head of an advertising agency, invites his colleagues to a [[whitewater rafting]] trip. The invitation feels more like an order to some, Cutler considering the outing a test of his employees' confidence, courage and skills. Retired agency executive Nick Karas is a last minute addition, wanting to help Cutler secure some clients and believing that it is a simple fishing trip. Tragedy occurs along Canada's "[[Chilko River|White Mile]]," when a canoe capsizes and several of Cutler's companions are swept away by the raging current. Two agency executives, retiree Karas and two clients die, and Cutler becomes at odds with Jack Robbins, one of his top executives, over how the aftermath should be portrayed to authorities and to relatives who are suing the company. == Cast == *[[Alan Alda]] as Dan Cutler *[[Peter Gallagher]] as Jack Robbins *[[Robert Loggia]] as Nick Karas *[[Bruce Altman]] as David Koenig *[[Fionnula Flanagan]] as Gena Karas *[[Jack Gilpin]] as Peter Wiederhorn *[[Ken Jenkins]] as Jerry Taggart *[[Dakin Matthews]] as Andy Thornell *[[Don McManus]] as Art Stefanoff *[[Robert Picardo]] as Tom Horton == Background== The film is loosely based on a rafting accident, on August 1, 1987, on the White Mile rapids in the Bidwell Canyon section of the [[Chilko River]], in the [[British Columbia Interior|Central Interior of British Columbia]], [[Canada]].{{cite news |url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/life/shooting-the-fraser-river-rapids/article25297142/?ref=https://www.theglobeandmail.com& |title=Shooting the Fraser River rapids |first=Bruce |last=Kirkby |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=2002-05-18 |accessdate=2017-09-25}} Current and retired executives of Chicago agency [[DDB Needham]] (DDB), along with clients from [[Kraft Foods Inc|Kraft]], [[Clorox]], [[Procter & Gamble]] (P&G), [[Drug Free America Foundation]] (DFAF) and other major companies, were involved in the incident.{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-02-13/business/9402130086_1_white-mile-procter-gamble-wolfe |publisher=Chicago Tribune |first=Nancy |last=Millman |title=A Morality Play on Business 'Responsibility' |date=1994-02-13 |accessdate=2017-09-25}} Like the film, five men died that day—two current and one retired DDB executives, and one executive each from P&G and DFAF. As in the film, the court assigned a payout of $1.1 million to the family of the retired DDB executive who died that day. == Awards and honors == *The film was nominated for two [[Golden Globes]]: "Best Mini-Series or Motion Picture Made for TV" and [[Alan Alda]] was nominated for "Best Performance by an Actor in a Mini-Series or Motion Picture Made for TV" *The film was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]] for "Outstanding Individual Achievement in Sound Editing for a Miniseries or a Special" *John Duffy was nominated for an [[ACE Eddie Awards|Eddie]] for "Best Edited Motion Picture for Non-Commercial Television" == Soundtrack == *"The Song of the Marines" by Harry Warren and Al Dubin == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{IMDb title|id=0111704}} {{Robert Butler}} [[Category:1994 television films]] [[Category:1990s thriller drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:American business films]] [[Category:American thriller drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about businesspeople]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Butler]] [[Category:HBO Films films]] [[Category:Rafting films]] {{US-tv-drama-film-stub}}

The '''World Counseling System (WCS)''', otherwise called the '''Religious Counseling Standard''', is a classification model developed for use mostly in religious counseling. It is a model commonly used for counseling in [[Africa]], [[Asia]] and [[South America]] and it works on three assumptions:
# That someone is concerned or confused about someone or there is an issue that needs to be resolved, usually urgently. # That the issue involved is such that it cannot be resolved through the person's own efforts. # That the inability to resolve the issue without outside assistance necessitates a recourse to a "higher being" who possesses superior wisdom. This higher being is expected to function through earthly agents.
This process involves the engagement of people with [[supernatural]] gifts such as [[prophet]]s (in whatever [[religion]]) and faith-based counselors to help resolve the problem. The core of the model is that the person with the problem commits his or her case into the hands of the agent of a [[supernatural being]] who is expected to proffer solutions to the problem.
Owing to the involvement of some supernatural being, the issues that can be resolved are unlimited, which makes categorization difficult. Categorization is based, therefore, on the personalities involved in the resolution process, rather than on the problems that need to be solved.
==Classifications== Under the WCS system, counseling is carried out in three categories: *Love/Personal relationships *Business relationships *Other relationships
If someone needs counseling in the area of [[personal relationship]], he or she could seek help from the agents regarding a spouse, boyfriend/girlfriend or [[Engagement|fiancée]]. He or she could ask such questions as "Is my husband faithful?" "Is this person the right person for me to marry?" and "If I marry this person, will the [[marriage]] last?" The online edition requires that you fill out a form. Information you need to supply includes your first name, the full name of the person you need information about, his or her mother's name and your question. When you send in your request, it is sent to at least two counselors. The agency using the WCS service will quickly prepare a composite report (from the two responses) which is sent back to you. The service comes at a fee since the WCS model has a [[copyright]] tied to it. An average response, which is usually more comprehensive than a typical on-line request, can take up to three hours before the reply is available. The response in a typical WCS service may have between 75 and 93 per cent accuracy in its [[prediction]]s regarding the issue to be resolved.
Similar processes apply to the "business" and "other" categories. For business classification, the question might be something like "I want to embark on this type of [[business]]. Will I succeed?" "Somebody wants to be my partner. Can this person be trusted?" "I want to obtain a [[loan]] from the bank. Will the loan bring profits?" "Will repayment of the loan be difficult?" The "other relationships" category takes care of areas not covered by personal and business relationships.
==References== 1. Singh M.H. (2003) Exploring the Religious Counseling Standard. Delhi: Hamil Publishing.
2. Kumar, Yadav (1994). Religious Counseling in Three Hindu Communities. ''Family Today, 7(2),'' 45-61.
